dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broken-knuckled, scab covered hands reach for the warmth the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Lornsome night. Babbits bawlin’, wind bitin’ t’bone. Zachry (50's) looks old, more weathered than aged, wearin mix of furs and strange futuristic armor. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Wind like this carries voices, ancestry howlin’ at’cha, screaming their stories, all their voices tied up in’t’one. On his face is a terrible scar, a brand burned into his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And out there’s you know who, spyin from the dark... Old Georgie and me crossed paths more times’n I’m comfy mem’ryn. After I’m died no tellin’ what that fangy devil won’t try to do to me... The fire glints in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen close and lemme yarn you ‘bout the first time we met eye to eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV ON a trail of footsteps in the sand... being followed by ADAM EWING (35), a lawyer from the city of Sa Francisco who appears out of place on the shore of this Pacific island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thus it was that I made the acquaintance of Doctor Henry Goose, surgeon of London nobility. The path leads to DR. HENRY GOOSE (mid-40’s), his trouser rolled up, sporting an unkempt beard as he shovels and si through the sand. EWING (CONT’D) Doctor Goose? Goose looks at Ewing, eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: And who might you be?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Ewing, Adam Ewing, Sir. Traveling with the “Prophetess”. They told me I could find you out here. Have you lost something?

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: (a beat, then smiles) Teeth, sir are the enameled grails of the quest at hand. This beach was once a cannibal’s banqueting hall, where the strong gorged on the weak, but the teeth, the teeth sir, they spat out as you or I would expel a cherry stone. An artisan of Piccadilly who fashions denture sets for the nobility pays handsomely for human gnashers. Do you know the price a quarter pound will earn, sir?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: I confess, I do not.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Nor shall I enlighten you, sir for ‘tis a professional secret. Ahhhhahahaha! The doctor has dentures himself; the teeth, overly large his mouth, give him a comedic and paradoxically carnivoro appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUISA REY (mid 30’s), a feminist from the days when it wa ideal, not a fashion statement, talks into her tape recor

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Question one: what secret might be in Sixsmith’s report that would be worth killing him for? Question two: if in fact someone did kill him, is it reasonable to assume they would kill again to protect that secret and if so, question three: what the fuck am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beetle rattles toward a small island dominated by a nuclear power plant cooling tower; a man-made volcano blo white smoke indifferently across a blue sky. The security booth is besieged by demonstrators wielding signs that scream, “Welcome to Cancer Island!” And “Hell We Won’t Glow!” She stops in front of the gate and the mirrored shade wea GUARD steps over.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Press pass.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Expecting trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ENFORCER hands a small wand-like device to the ARCHIVI aman in his early thirties.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Any problems sir, you just hit this button.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Thank you. The Enforcer leaves them alone. The glow panel hums above them.  The Archivist sits across from SONMI-451, a young female replicant, who watches him, her magnetic shackles, secure locked to the armrests. He removes the “orison”, an egg-shaped recording device, its case. He sets it upright and it begins to spin. ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) On behalf of my Ministry and the future of Unanimity, I want to thank you for this final interview. Her genetically designed features remain a mask of servil patience. ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) Remember this isn’t an interrogation or a trial. Your version of the truth is all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Truth is singular. Its “versions” are mistruths. The noise of an old typewriter in use cuts into the silen INT. CAVENDISH’S STUDY - EVENING - YEAR 2009 A beautiful English study; bookshelves line the walls. Timothy Cavendish, an older man is typing his memoir into typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: While my extensive experience as an editor has led me to a disdain for flashbacks and flash forwards and all such tricksy gimmicks I believe that if you, dear Reader, can extend your patience for just a moment, you will find there is a Method to this tale of Madness. He pauses, considering, then sips the last of his wine be continuing.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look. I was Dermot Hoggins's publisher, not his shrink or his astrologer, the ruddy, bloody truth is I had no idea what the man was going to do that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT FROBISHER (early 20’s) looks as though he has been for days. He places an envelope carefully on the desk, ju above a manuscript entitled “The Cloud Atlas Sextet.”

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: My Dearest Sixsmith. I shot myself through the roof of my mouth at four AM this morning with Vyvyan Ayrs’ Luger. He goes to the bathroom and wraps his head in a towel. He gets into the tub and picks up the Luger pistol. FROBISHER (CONT’D) A true suicide is a paced, disciplined certainty. People pontificate, “suicide is selfishness,” while career churchmen like Pater call ita coward’s act typically because they lack the necessary suffering to sympathize. Couldn’t be further from the truth; suicide takes tremendous courage. He puts the gun in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t let them say I killed myself for love. Had my infatuations but we both know in our hearts who is the sole love of my short, bright life. As he cocks back the hammer and prepares to pull the trig we cut to black.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: On a background of swirling nimbi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man and his two sons push an overloaded archaic looking hand cart along a muddy wooded trail. They stop at a ford along a river bed, the sun low in the sky.  6. Helping them, without exerting much effort is Zachry who recognize, though he is a decade younger and does not hav the terrible scar.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For me, all started way back when I still had mos’ my teeth. Me an’ Adam, my bro’by law, an his two sons was trekkin' back from Honokaa Market. Evenin' catched us up early, so we tented on the southly bank o' Sloosha's Crossin'. Zachry'’s brother-in-law, Adam and his two sons begin to up a makeshift camp. ZACHRY (V.O.) (CONT’D) Now, I'd got diresome hole-spew that day ‘cos I'd ate a gammy dog leg in Honokaa, an' I was squattin' in a thicket when sudd'nwise I felt the devil’s eyes on me. Zachry defecates in a leafy brush when he feels as though is not alone. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Who's there? The hairs on his neck stand up.

dialogues.speaker: CREEPY VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, a darky spot you're in, friend.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Name y'self! Zachry yanks out his weapon.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a blade, I have! The voice hisses at him.

dialogues.speaker: CREEPY VOICE
dialogues.text: Ain’t no blade can protect you from the True-true... Perched above him, wrapped in dusky shadow is OLD GEORGIE devil dressed in black tatters and a battered stovepipe h his spindly arms and legs unfold from beneath him spider- as he stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared, whispers) Old Georgie... The devil cackles. ZACHRY (V.O.) (CONT’D) I knowed the moment he looked me dead t’eye, my soul was stoned. Suddenly, Old Georgie LEAPS DOWN at Zachry who screams -- staggers, hiking up his pants and runs away, crashing thr the brush straight into a clearing-- Filled with savage-looking tattooed men astride armored horses: KONA RAIDERS. The blood drains from his face as Zachry freezes for a moment, then turns and bolts. They howl as they rear their horses in chase. The underbrush tears at Zachry as he sprints back to his camp. The taunting shrieks of the Kona and the thundering hooves of horses swirl around him, closing fast. Zachry can feel them almost on top of him when his foot g caught by a root and he suddenly drops, disappearing into thick bed of leaves. The horses scream past him. He lets out a breath, still shaking from the chase but as sounds of the raiders recede, he hears their SHOUTS rise renewed. He realizes he has led the Kona to Adam and his two sons.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now panickin' wings your foot but it muddies your thinkin' too, so I rabbited back to camp. I jus' followed my instinct without thinkin' thru what'd happen. Zachry scrambles from his hiding place and carefully worm his way to the edge of the camp. The Kona have surrounded Zachry’s brother-in-law and neph hooting at them as they toy with their prey. He watches as Adam swings his axe defensively when the cr of a bullwhip sends him to his knees.  Another crack and the axe is torn from his hands. Zachry lies paralyzed by fear as Old Georgie seems to materialize from the shadows beside him; at first, the malevolent smile is the only thing visible.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Yay, stay here. Saaaaaaafe here. Ain’t no sense in trying to help’em. You’ve said it y’self many times, ain’t ya? “The Weak are Meat, the Strong do Eat.” The True-true, what that is. No un‘scapes the True-true. Horror, like a hand of ice, squeezes Zachry’s heart as th KONA CHIEF grabs a handful of Adam’s hair and wrenches ba his head. His blade flashes as he slits his throat from e to ear. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Shame but Adam’s too old for slavin’. Ain’t fit for nuthin’ but feedin’ worms. His youngest nephew screams and attacks but he his quickl and violently subdued. The older boy tries to protect his brother but is also bludgeoned into submission. The two boys are thrown over a horse as the Kona prepare depart.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dem boys a’ headed t’slave markets. Ain’t nuthin’ y’can do t’stop it. ‘Sides who’s gonna look after your sister and little Catkin? This thought takes away some of the pain and horror of wh Zachry has just experienced.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yay, think ‘bout Catkin and Rose. Makes thinkin’ about y’self so much easier... don’t it? The face fades back into the darkness while the smile lingers, dissolving into a patch of leafy crepuscular lig Alone, Zachry looks at Adam’s body and begins to weep.  9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A contract is being signed.

dialogues.speaker: EWING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Wednesday, 9th of September. The contracts are signed. My father-in- law should be happy. Reverend Horrox sits across from Ewing and finishes the l signature. EWING (V.O.) (CONT’D) All my worrying due to the delay caused by my failing health seems fatuous. A bit of good fortune-- Doctor Henry Goose had offered to accompany me back to San Francisco and treat me. How I long for this journey to end, to be home again, to be in Tilda’s arms. Close on a pool of smoking red wax as a seal is pressed i it. Above the seal is the signature of Reverend Giles Hor of the London Missionary Society.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: There you are, Mr.Ewing. As binding a covenant there can ever be between men outside the province of Scripture.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Thank you, Reverend Horrox. I know my father-in-law is profoundly excited about this deal.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: Your father-in-law is a great man. Future generations depend upon men like him; men capable of speaking the truth. Ewing nods like someone used to living in someone else’s shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam Ewing and Goose sup on turtle soup with the Horrox family and a few members of his clergy.  10.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: When I first encountered Haskell Moore’s writing, its perspicuity struck me as if delivered through Divine revelation. Goose slurps his soup. HORROX (CONT’D) Doctor Goose, a learned man such as yourself must be familiar with his tractus, “The Ladder of Civilization?”

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: I confess, Reverend, my education remains a work in progress.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: How providential your choice of words Doctor, for Progress is precisely the subject. Specifically the kind of Progress that we see here in Bethlehem Bay everyday. But I’m sure Mr. Ewing would be better at explaining the work of his father-in-law than I. Attention shifts to Ewing, who sets his spoon down with a muted clatter against the taurine.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see. It is, in essence, a syllogistic exploration of God’s Will.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME PARISHIONER
dialogues.text: (to Goose) I couldn’t understand a word of it Doctor, but when the Reverend explained it in one of his homilies, well, the whole parish felt the presence of our Lord.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: Continue, Mr. Ewing.  11.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Of course, he acknowledges that God's Will remains ultimately unknowable, but he suggests that if the miracles of the Biblical Age, can be interpreted as a manifestation of His Will then perhaps that same Hand is responsible for the miracles of Progress. In this Age he argues, it is Progress that elevates man towards his Creator, not Jacob’s Ladder, but rather “Civilization’s Ladder,” that bears us towards the Godhead. Madame Parishioner hums in corseted pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: This explains the advancement of each race, why you have the Anglo- Saxon at the high-point on the ladder, nearest God and the “irreclaimable races” such as the Aboriginal and the African or even our own Moriori, who remain one rung up from the great ape, so obdurate to Progress and to the Word of God, that no one should be surprised when one of them slips off the ladder altogether.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: You mean extinction?

dialogues.speaker: HORROX
dialogues.text: Surely a Doctor knows that God’s Will is often an act of mercy.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME PARISHIONER
dialogues.text: Amen. Heads are bowed and “amens” mumbled amidst the flickering candle flames. Goose looks at Ewing who has trouble meeting his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young byronic Frobisher lies entwined with his lover RUFUS SIXSMITH; deep shadows cleaved into the tangle of sheets frame their coital, luminous flesh.  12. On Frobisher’s back, just below his shoulder there is a strange comet-shaped birth mark.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sixsmith - I do hope you will be able to find it in your heart... to forgive me. A terrible pounding on the door, jolts the lovers awake.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL HEAVY
dialogues.text: Mr. Frobisher! Mr. Robert Frobisher! Sixsmith starts to the door but Frobisher stops him thoug the pounding grows more urgent. HOTEL HEAVY (CONT’D) The management would like a word, sir! Mr. Frobisher, open this door! Sixsmith looks at Frobisher, knowing exactly what is abou happen; his lover’s eyes shine in a way that often requir an apology. HOTEL HEAVY (CONT’D) We know you’re in there, Mr. Frobisher. Please, comply! A letter is being drafted to your father! Mr. Frobisher! As the pounding continues, Frobisher slips on most of his clothes including a beautiful waistcoat. As he puts it on he smiles at Sixsmith who smiles back knowing he is about to lose his favorite vest. They stare at one another as if they were the only two pe in the world until Frobisher kisses him one last time. The kiss ends like a spell breaking, the pounding even lo as Frobisher dashes across the room, grabs his small bag Leaps out the window. There is a metal shriek of a bending drainpipe which caus Sixsmith to rush to the window wrapped only in a sheet. Outside, Frobisher thuds to a lower roof below, then with certain awkward aplomb, slips down over the eave and drop the alley below.  13. He sees Sixsmith watching and he bows as though taking a final curtain, gestures as if he was throwing his heart a Sixsmith, flashes a rakish smile and darts away just as-- The door bursts open.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hated leaving you like that. Wasn’t the goodbye I had in mind at all. But you more than anyone understand the precariousness of my present predicament. Sixsmith smiles with resignation and reaches for his wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher writes his letter as the city is smeared with a impressionist’s brush behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sure you'd remind me I brought it all upon myself, Sixsmith, but shrug off that middle-class chip on your shoulder and try to stick with me a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith sits on a park bench, reading Frobisher’s letter

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This time it’s going to be different, I swear to you. This time I have a plan. In the Belgian backwaters, south of Bruges, there lives a reclusive English composer, named Vyvyan Ayrs. You won't have heard of him because you're a musical oaf, but he's one of the greats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher gets off the train and heads for the exit.  14.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He hasn't produced any new work since the early twenties due to illness - but the Times review of last week’s performance of his Secular Magnificat referred to a drawer full of unfinished works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith, reading, sadly senses his love traveling furthe and further away.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You see where this is heading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd boards the ferry. Frobisher is among them.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My scheme had me traveling to Belgium, persuading Vyvyan Ayrs he needed to employ me as an amanuensis, accepting his offer to tutor me, shooting through the musical firmament, winning fame and fortune commensurate to my gifts, obliging Pater to admit that, yes, the son he disinherited is the Robert Frobisher, greatest British composer of his time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher sits on the deck, finishing his letter, the chi channel wind fondling his hair.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know, Sixsmith, you groan and shake your head, but you smile too, which is why I love you. A pretty SAILOR smiles at Frobisher as he puts his letter away. He smiles back. The sailor heads below deck as Frobisher, feeling his luck begin to change, follows. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) P.S. Thanks for the waistcoat. I needed something of yours to keep me company.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith sighs, a hint of a smile like the taste of bittersweet, fading as he folds the letter and tucks it i a new leather bag as we hear--

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come on, baaaaby, we are meant to be together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a bag that could be Sixsmith’s, but worn and age a point beyond resemblance. An old man stands waiting for an elevator. Out of the cor of his eye he looks towards the voices and the sounds of party spilling out of an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: Luisaaaaa, I’m tellin you baby, you can’t leave me. It’s a past life thing or maybe a future life, but I feel it, you and me. A man too old for his leather trousers, bare torso and ze waistcoat, one arm wrapped around Luisa’s waist, the othe holding a joint.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Not tonight, sorry. Thanks again for the interview, but really, I need to get home.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, what you need is to lighten up, baby. He takes a long hit.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: En-lighten up. Come on, one little magic carpet ride. The elevator dings and she looks at the old man who turns away as the doors slide open.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Look, just so there’s no uncertainty, I’d jump to my death before I’d ride a magic carpet with you.  16. She pries herself free as the old man gets on the elevato

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: Pick-ky! Who do you think you are? Joni-fuckin-Mitchell? She runs for the doors that begin to close.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Elevator!

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: You write a bullshit gossip column for a fuckin rag! You’re a NOBODY! The elevator doors are closing just as Luisa reaches them a cane suddenly jams between them, forcing them open.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Thank you. The OLD MAN nods. LUISA REY (CONT’D) Nice to know the Age of Chivalry isn’t dead. He manages a smile but it is obvious that he is not a hea man. In his hand is the small suitcase. They watch the needle leisurely arc its way towards the “ until a gatta-gatta-gatta detonates-- The elevator abruptly lurches to a stop and dies with a mechanical scream. Both Luisa and the old man crash to the ground by the sud impact. Luisa picks herself up as the light stutters on and off before settling on a buzzing sepia. The sprawled man recovers himself a little. LUISA REY (CONT’D) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: No bones broken, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Let me help you.  17.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Thanks but I’1l just stay seated for the moment in case it restarts suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Feels like another power outage. Perfect end to the perfect day. She hits the ancient intercom button. LUISA REY (CONT’D) Hey anyone there? We’re trapped! Can anyone hear me? Static hiss. LUISA REY (CONT’D) Christ. She looks up for a ceiling hatch. LUISA REY (CONT’D) There’s gotta be an access hatch... There isn’t. She looks at the old man.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only in the movies, I guess. She resigns, sitting down across from him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Still glad the Age of Chivalry isn’t dead? She manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I'd still rather be here than back up there.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Not your cup of tea, was he? She snorts.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: More like an occupational hazard.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: What occupation might that be, if it’s not inappropriate to ask?  18.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Journalist to some, bullshit gossip columnist to others. She reaches her hand out. He shakes She pulls LUISA REY (CONT’D) Luisa Rey. it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Rey? Any relation to Lester Rey? her hand back and shrinks a little.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah... he was my father.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Really? Do you know, I subscribed to Illustrated Planet in ‘67 just to read your father’s dispatches from Vietnam. One of the few journalists who grasped the war from the Asian perspective.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I think I read that he had been a policeman, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: But I recall there was some kind of trial, some malfeasance?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: My dad could never play the game, so they kicked him out.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: And then he became a journalist?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: More like a Crusader.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Remarkable.  19.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He realizes just how painful the nerve is that he hit.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: He must have been very proud of you, following in his footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Oh, Luisa Rey is no Lester Rey. No award winning copy from war zones. No exclusive interviews with the leaders of the Black Panther party. She’s done nothing with her life but crank out a bit of simpering gossip for a celebrity rag no one ever admits to reading.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but is it well written, simpering gossip?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Oh, it is excellently written simpering gossip.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Then don’t bemoan any misspent life quite yet. Forgive me for flaunting my experience but you have no conception what a misspent life constitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awards night for book publishers held at a posh bar wi rooftop garden overlooking the city. In the background, a jazz sextet plays quietly.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Twas the Night of the Lemon Prizes, no bigger waste of time in the entire publishing industry. Cavendish stands alone looking out over the rooftops. Beh him, the party crowd: a cloud of critics, compliers, commentators - and writers.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I recall a moment of introspection, at the balcony’s edge, contemplating a change of vocation, why, why would anyone in their right mind choose to be a publisher? Which was when he found me. Bad news inexorably does.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: oy, Timothy. DERMOT HOGGINS sidles up beside Cavendish. DERMOT (CONT’D) It’s all fockin’ bullshit, mate. A fockin’ waste.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Probably true, but we never really know what actual effect we have in the Great Scheme of Things. Remember poor Melville; writes a ripping yarn about a big white whale which is summarily dismissed, laughed at by critics, rejected by readers yet, today, lugged around in the backpacks of every serious student of literature in the Western world.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: I don’t give a fock wot ‘appens when I’m dead. I want people to buy my book now.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: As your publisher, obviously nothing would make me happier but for whatever reason, “Knuckle Sandwich” failed to connect to an audience.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: You want a reason? I’11 show you a fockin’ reason. Right there! He points as though aiming a gun at a smiling MAN, thorou enjoying himself. Cavendish immediately recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ahh, you mean, Mr. Finch?  21.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: Felix Fockin’ Finch! The cunt that shat on my book in his poncy fockin’ magazine!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t your best review.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: It was my only fockin’ review!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that bad. He pulls a wadded piece of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: No? (reading) “Mr. Hoggins should apologize to the trees felled for his bloated autobio-novel. Four hundred vainglorious pages expire in an ending that is flat and inane beyond belief.” Dermot flings his glass over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Steady now, Dermot. What’s a critic but one who reads quickly, arrogantly but never wisely.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: Fockit. He heads for Finch.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Dermot... Swiping two cocktail trays from passing servers he starts banging them together.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman of the jury! Your attention, please! Finch and his gaggle of admirers turn as Dermot bears dow them.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have an additional award tonight, fellow book faeries! Ooooh’s and chuckles all around Dermot.  22. DERMOT (CONT’D) An award for “Most Eminent Critic!” Competition was fierce but - (he produces a crumbled piece of paper) the panel was unanimous in choosing, Mr.- oh, beg pardon, SIR Felix Finch 0, B and E! Stirrers crow “Bravo, Felix, bravo.”

dialogues.speaker: FINCH
dialogues.text: What might my prize be, I wonder? A signed copy of an unpulped “Knuckle Sandwich?” Can’t be many of those left. The coterie hoots. Dermot seethes. FINCH (CONT’D) Well come on, I’m breathless with anticipation. Just what does that lead-less pencil you call an imagination have in mind to end this scene? The tension goes out of Dermot’s face and he winks.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT
dialogues.text: Oh, I think you’re gonna love this one. He grabs hold of Finch’s lapels, spins him around and wit surprising nonchalance- Judo throws the critic over the balcony railing. Finch’s shriek ends with a terrible wet THUD on the pavem below. The force of the splatter sets off a car alarm. Dermot dusts his lapels and calls over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: DERMOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, THAT’S “an ending flat and inane beyond belief.” The crowd stands dumbstruck, quiet enough to hear champag bubbling as Dermot saunters back to the bar and orders a beer. MOVING IN on Cavendish who watches him, his horror slowly fading as he begins to sense something gathering momentum like music in his head.  23.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My thoughts? If I am honest, I admit that the obvious emotions like shock and horror, flew as Finch had, here and gone, while deep down I experienced a nascent sense of a silver lining to this most tragic turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newspapers and magazines are covered with pictures of Der and Finch, (headlines like “WRITER:1 CRITIC:0” or “Finch’ Final Fling”).

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Overnight, Dermont “Dusty” Hoggins became a cult hero to the Common Man. Television News and Talk Shows all circle around the scan of the month. In a quick montage, we can see more and mor monitors, “Knuckle Sandwich” being discussed on every channel.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have been asked on numerous occasions, what is feels like to be at the center of a media storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish is besieged by a blockade of reporters as he tr to get to his office door.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Save perhaps the blood and the dying, I imagine it feels not unlike being at the center of a shark attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes himself in and manages to hold back the wave microphone-wielding zombies.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: However, since there is very little that can be done to stop it...  24. He locks the door and turns looking a bit discombobulated Across the room, MRS. LATHAM stands wringing her hands. Cavendish reaches into his coat pocket and pulls out a bo of Dom Perignon.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One may as well try to enjoy it. He smiles which causes her to smile and giggle.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The highest selling Cavendish title prior to the Dermont sweepstakes was a cookbook penned by Princess Diana’s former horse-groomer. It sold 5,214 copies. A moment later the champagne pops and bubbly froth gushes while on the television in the background-- A smiling Dermont is led towards the courthouse, through human sea of reporters, cameras bobbing like the remains shipwreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old fashioned printing press chugs along, spitting out title pages that read: “Knuckle Sandwich, A Novel of My L by Dermot “Dusty” Hoggins.”

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: “Knuckle Sandwich” shifted 300 hundred thousand, yes, THREE HUNDRED thousand copies in less than two months, and yes, I am still talking hardcover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A window is being filled with a major display for glossy hardcovers of “Knuckle Sandwich.”

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The American publishers, glory glory Hallelujah, they loved the Limey-Aristo-Gets-Comeuppance-from- Downtrodden-Gaelic-Son hook, and a transatlantic auction skyrocketed the advance to giddy heights.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close as Cavendish opens an envelope. Mrs. Latham stands behind him. When they see the six figure number, she shri

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I, yes, I, Timothy Cavendish, had exclusive rights to this platinum goose with a bad case of the trots!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand plucks the final “Knuckle Sandwich” from the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window is opened and Cavendish leans out, looking dow the garbage in the alley below.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yet, being a good North Londoner, which is to say, a devout pessimist, it wasn’t until the check arrived from Hollywood for the rights to the feature film that is in production as I write this, that I distinctly recall the exultation of emancipation. From the window he pitches his old, battered chair which shatters on the cobblestones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish leans back bouncing gently in his new high-tech Aeron chair. Mrs. Latham spins like a child in her new chair.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They say success can change a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish stands in his underwear, surrounded by the best tailors money can by, flipping through several fabric swatches as he is measured.  26.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I say, the only thing success changes, is your options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish wearing his new suit leans back luxuriantly as talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And of course, your phone sheet. People who wouldn’t have taken the time to scrape me off their shoe were calling on the hour. Mrs. Latham signals to him, holding a sign with the name “McCarthy” to which Cavendish shakes his head with thorou enjoyed superciliousness, before returning to his call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish exits after a magnificent day, looking as dappe he feels. He locks the office door and strides down the small street, his shiny new walking stick clicking smartl against the cobblestones.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was for the briefest of moments, Cinderella, living inside my dream come true, but alas and alack, all dreams perish whence the ticking clock of reality sounds its alarm. Behind him, a car with dark tinted windows starts up and glides in pursuit with the grace of a predatory cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orison spins as the Archivist speaks as though readin from a legal brief.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Ordinarily, I begin by asking prisoners to recall their earliest memories to provide a context for the corpocratic historians of the future.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Fabricants have no earliest memories, Archivist. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One twenty-four-hour cycle in Papa Song's is indistinguishable from any other.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Then why not describe this "cycle.”

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: If you wish. INT. PAPA SONG’S GALLEY - YELLOW UP - YEAR 2144 The cloned servers lay sleeping in pods. Above them a dim ochre glow seeps out from several orbs. Inside one pod, a slightly colored gas swirls waking Sonmi. The pod opens and she climbs out simultaneously with the other clones. No one speaks.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A server is woken at hour four- thirty by stimulin in the airflow. They file one by one into the hygiener, then proceed with assembly line precision to a small locker room where chemically cleaned uniforms arrive just as they do.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After a minute in the hygiener and steamer, we put on fresh uniforms before filing into the dinery. INT. PAPA SONG’S - YELLOW UP - MONTAGE - YEAR 2144 As the lights come up throughout the restaurant, the clon gather for their morning ritual prayer at the plinth of t logoman.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At Yellow-Up, we gather around Papa Song's Plinth for Matins. We recite the Six Catechisms, then our beloved Logoman appears and delivers his Sermon. The Logoman appears as a gigantic 3D hologram and deliver his morning sermon that feels like a recording of someone reading from, “Inspirational Quote of the Day.”  28.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At hour five we man our tellers around the Hub, ready for the elevator to bring the new day's first consumers. Consumers begin to arrive and the clones go to work, delivering food and drinks, smiling, moving with efficien honed through repetition.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the following nineteen hours we greet diners, input orders, tray food, vend drinks, upstock condiments, wipe tables, and bin garbage all performed in strict adherence to First Catechism.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is the First Catechism? Sonmi cleans the floor as a gang of TEENAGERS hurries pas her--

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Honor Thy Consumer.” One of them throwing a smack across her ass. She looks at him, her eyes pinned, her feelings hidden beneath her servant’s smile. They all laugh and tumble in the elevator outside of the dinery. INT. PAPA SONG’S GALLEY - NIGHT Sonmi sits in her sleep-wear, sipping from her packet of Soap.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vespers follows final cleaning, then we imbibe one Soapsac in the dormroom. That is the blueprint of every unvarying day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we see her again we realize how different she is fro the servant she used to be.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: What did you do during your free- time?  29.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Only purebloods are entitled to "free-time," Archivist. He shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. He consults his notes. ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) Did you ever think about the future?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Papa Song server’s only have one possible long-term future.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: You mean, “Xultation?” She nods, her eyes like the empty stare of a gun. ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) Could you describe this annual Rite of Passage? INT. PAPA SONG’S - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 An ADV instreams images of paradise. The clones gather around the 3D Holo-projection, impresse the stores and elegantly decorated malls filled with ever conceivable consumable.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After Matins on First Day, Seer Rhee would pin a star on every server's collar. SEER RHEE, Papa Song’s clone supervisor, pins the final 1 star on one of Sonmi’s sisters. Her sisters are excited a they seem capable of being, each hugging her. SONMI-451 (V.O.) (CONT’D) For the “Twelvestarred” it is a Momentous occasion. Twelve stars, we believed meant an end to our contract, an end to our life as servers.  30. The clone is led by several Papa Song Aides to the bank o elevators.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How did you feel when you watched on of your sisters Ascend? She rises up, a wide smile on her face as they catch a fi glimpse of her.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Excitement. I was happy for them. But envious as well Sonmi realizes that one of her sisters is not looking up the elevator bank. Instead she is playing with something that glints in the light. Something that looks like a key This is Yoona-939.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did your sister servers feel as you did? Yoona looks up and catches Sonmi staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: +--most of them. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’d like to ask you about the infamous Yoona-939. Yoona hides the key and smiles the kind of smile that can shared only by two people in the same prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The memory wells inside Sonmi’s mind like a tear.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Our relationship began... with a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful view from a cliff, overlooking the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Uncle Zach, look!  31. An enormous hovercraft cruises towards the island, across glittering bay.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Yay, I see’em. ZACHRY (V.O.) (CONT’D) The Prescients came to Big Isle for barterin’ twice a year. Zachry sits on a rock, his goats scattered around him. Hi ten year old niece CATKIN sits beside him, staring at the miraculous ship. ZACHRY (V.O.) (CONT’D) Their ship weren’t no mythy yarnin’ either, creep-crawlin over the waves, no sails, no oars, just floatin’ on the Smart o’ the Old Uns. A bell clangs in the distance followed by the screams of excited children.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: The Great Barter’1l be startin’ soon.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Aye. Best go find ya’ma. She nods excited, jumps off the rock but then stops.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Wha‘bout you? Ya’comin’?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Time was, I’d go skeeddlin, down the hill to meet those ships, elboin’ my way to the front jus’ like ev’run else. Zachry looks at the ships docking and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But after Sloosha’s Crossin’, I ain’t had the taste for howzittin’ or smilesome yaysayin’.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Som’uns’ gotta mind these knob head’d buggahs. Y’go on.  32. Catkin can’t bring herself to leave her uncle. She climbs back on the rock. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Wha’cha doin’?

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: I best stay with you.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Mamma say ya ain’t been right since Sloosha’s. She said I gotta keep my eye on ya. Zachry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: So, y’mindin’ me, while I mind the goats. She nods authoritatively. ZACHRY (CONT’D) I see, I see. But she can’t hide the disappointment at missing the Bart

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the problem is, whose gonna mind your ma at the Great Barter? Y’know she got no tongue for hagglin’. Not like you’n’me. What if she gives away the ‘hole house? Where we gonna sleep? She brightens.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nope. No, bolt hole out of it. You best get down there, rabbit quick’n’mind your ma for it’s too late. Hurry! She jumps down again.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Y’sure you’ll be al’right?  33.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I promise. I’11 be home for suppin, as long as we got som’where t’sup. Now, go on! Smiling, she races down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry herds the goats towards the slumping building that his family’s home. There is quite a crowd gathered outside. People are looki at him and whispering.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sincewise, thoughts worm ‘round my head and I wonder if I’d gone to the Great Barter, could I’ave cold watered the ‘hole plan, could I’ve stopped all the diresome things that were about to happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry walks in and is immediately shocked by what he see Prescient woman, MERONYM, sitting at the table with his sister ROSE and niece CATKIN.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Uncle Zach! Uncle Zach! Lookey what Meronym give me! She rushes over to display her glittering new necklace. CATKIN (CONT’D) And ma gots some spesh new ironware pot and I knows Meronym’s got a pressie for you too! Zachry looks suspiciously at the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What’s goin’ on here, sis?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: We hostin’ a spesh guest, first ever Prescient t’live wit’a Valleysman. Meronym I’d like to intro our man a’the house, my older bro, Zachry.  34. Meronym glides gracefully from her seat to Zachry. Her sk much smoother than any Valleysman, is the color of rich, chocolate. Her blue eyes catch his stare like steel against flint. She reaches her hand out but he ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I’m thankin’ ya kindly for hostin’ my stay in the Valley.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I ain’t saysooed this, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Abbess says it’s a great honor.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Why don’t she host her then?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: ‘Hole Valley knows we got room since Sloosha’s. The use of Sloosha’s is like a quick snap of his achilles tendon.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I brought you a gift, Zachry--

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Don’t need no gift from a stranger. He pushes past her and goes to his room.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I don’t wan’ta ‘cause no strife.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He’ll be right. He’s like a goat, stubborn, hatin’ anything diff’rent. I’11 bake him a spice cake and he’1ll be right. INT. BAILEY DWELLIN’ - NIGHT - YEAR 2321 It seems like the entire tribe of valleymen has crammed themselves into the Bailey’s home, all come to see the Prescient woman now living there. They ogle her strange clothes, beautiful skin and “smart gear.”  35. Zachry sits alone in a corner eating a big slice of spice cake.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now kin'n'bros'n'lastlife fam'ly'n'half-strangers, yay, ev'ryun from Mauka to Mormon came knockin' to see if Old Ma Yibber spoke it true, that a real'n'livin' Prescient was stayin' at Bailey's. An' they gaped in wonderment like Sonmi herself was sittin' in our kitchen. A little boy touches her skin as if trying to rub off the darkness. Meronym smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Questions ‘bout Prescience an' their whoahsome Ship came pourin' thick'n'fast. Why Prescients'd all got dark skins like cokeynuts. Why weren't Prescience Isle on any map? How old do Prescients live? A TRIBESMAN with particularly gravity defying hair raises hand.

dialogues.speaker: TRIBESMAN
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Forty. Everyone reacts with whispers, impressed, but also in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Livin' to forty ain't wondersome, nay, livin' to forty an’lookin like she looked is eery an' ain't nat'ral. But the true wyrd thing was, Meronym seemed to answer the questions, but her answers didn't quench your curio none.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TRIBESMAN
dialogues.text: What makes your Ship move?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Fusion engines. The room murmurs, nodding. “Oh-fusion engines it is. Aye, aye.”  36.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: No un asked what "fusion engines" was ‘cos they din't want to look barb'ric or stoopit in front o' the gath'rin'. All-o-that answerin’ done was teached ev'ryun to step slywise an' not trust her, nay, not a flea. Chewing his cake like a goat, Zachry watches her out of t corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: She a sly’un. The camera dollies revealing Old Georgie, his thin lips whispering into Zachry’s ear. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Schemin’ and wormin’ herself in. Watch her, watch her close. She’s got seeeecrets. INT. BAILEY DWELLIN’ ZACHRY’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2321 It is late. Zachry is still awake in his bed, insects dro like an alarm. He concentrates as he hears something from the next room. After a beat he gets up. INT. BAILEY DWELLIN’ MERONYM’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2321 Through the cracked curtain doorway of Meronym’s room see faint watery glow. Zachry creeps up to it his eyes narrowing as he hears voi Inside he sees Meronym sitting on the floor, her back to quietly talking into an eerie blue glow. Zachry hears a m voice responding to her but can’t quite hear what they ar saying. She finishes. Something clicks and the light goes out as Meronym rises. When she turns we see that Zachry is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewing and Goose are given a tour of the plantation by D’Arnoqg.  37. D’ARNOQ Reverend Horrox real specific on how he wants the plantation run. The Georgian Way, best way, he say. The sun bathes the scene with migraine-inducing white lig D’ARNOQ (CONT’D) The crop is mix of Nicotania Tabacum and Perique. Some Criolla we grow on the side of hill over there which can be treated for pipe or cigars. They walk through the fields where the workers are cuttin the leaves. Ewing is soaked with sweat, his sallow skin hanging like dirty washcloth around his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: The heat... it’s unbearable. He mops his forehead, looking at the toiling laborers. D’Arnog watches him, unable to say what he would like to EWING (CONT’D) How do they take it? D’ARNOQ Reverend Horrox says they like the camel, bred for the desert. He says they don’t feel heat like civilized folk. Goose smiles, while examining Ewing.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: It appears the good Reverend understands physiology as well as he does theosophy. (to Ewing) We should get you out of the sun. Ewing slowly realizes that the “humming” in his ears is steadily growing louder.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Do you hear that noise? D’ARNOQ It’s coming from the camp.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camp is surrounded by a stake fence. A hairless older NATIVE raises her head as D’Arnog leads Ewing and Goose p The entire camp is gathered around a whipping post. Most sitting on the dirt, rocking slightly as their voices vib at the bottom of their throats. There are two distinct classes of race, one lighter than other. A chieftain occupies a throne wearing a feathered cloak. Tattooed gentry, womenfolk and children remain transfixed the violence. The WHIP MASTER is a Goliath, covered in lizard tattoos. With each excoriating lash, the VICTIM shudders; his back vellum of bloody runes. Ewing almost swoons as the next blow falls and in that moment, the victim raises his head-- And looks straight at Ewing and, as if in recognition-- The man reaches one of his bloody hands out, almost point towards Ewing. Ewing is unable to turn away and as the lash falls lacera flesh, blood and bits of flesh misting the air around the head and shoulders-- Ewing feels a nausea sweep through his body as-- He faints. INT. THE MUSKET - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 Ewing wakes as Goose applies a cold rag to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Ahhhh, there you are. Welcome back. Consciousness bobs in the pools of his watery eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: ++. what happened? He looks at Ewing’s dilated pupils.  39.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: It is as I suspected: Gusano Coco Cervello better known as the Polynesian Worm. I once saw a man’s brain after the Worm had finished with him-- like maggoty cauliflower, but fear not, this particular devil and I are well acquainted. The doctor listens to his heart with an odd stethoscope, noticing as he does a comet-shaped birthmark just above Ewing’s heart.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: It was the strangest experience of my life, Henry. I tell you, I could feel the lash, feel it as real as your hand. I felt it land and... Goose begins to mix a compound from his apothecary.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: A sensorial hallucination probably brought on by heatstroke and the worm’s reaction to the vermicide. As the parasite dies, its poison sacs will often split and secrete. These kinds of experiences are not uncommon.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: You're the doctor, you’re probably right...

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: I know I am. Now then, urussium alkali and orinoco manganese to pacify our friend and finally, a little laphrydictic myrrh to disintegrate it. He fills an ivory spoon and hands it to Ewing. GOOSE (CONT’D) Here we go-- Ewing inhales the medicine up into his nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I would have done had our paths not crossed.  40.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Well for starters, you would have died. His laugh is like the first shovel of dirt on a metal cof GOOSE (CONT’D) I suggest we leave the good Reverend to marvel at the miracles of Providence and the inexplicable ways that two people can be brought together at just the right moment. As a man of Science I prefer to suckle at the largess of Serendipity with a tip of the hat and a “don’t mind if I do.” Ewing tears with gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: You are as precious to me, my friend, as any diamond.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: You should feel better, very quickly, Adam. A good night’s sleep and you should be ready for the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat arrives at the port of Bruges. Frobisher disembarks, the young seaman pointing, giving h directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher strobes past the rows of Italian poplars, coat flapping, gravel flying as he coasts up to the stately mansion on a bicycle. A muscle-bound VALET working on a Cowley Flat Nose, wipes hands as he moves to stop Frobisher. Frobisher hops off his bike, leans it against the wall an strides forward without any intention of being stopped.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I have business with your master.  4l. On the porch, sitting in a wheelchair beneath foamy wiste listening to the radio, is VYVYAN AYRS, mid-70s, though h illness has ravaged him, there remains a vitality behind sharpness of his eyes. Frobisher stops on the cinder path and kneels like Perciv to King Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Who in the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: It’s a great honor ---

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: I said who in the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Robert Frobisher, sir, from Saffron Walden. I am - I was - a student of Sir Trevor Mackerras at Caius College, and I've come all the way from London to -

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: All the way from London on a bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I borrowed the bicycle in Bruges.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Did you? Must have taken hours.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: A labor of love sir. Like pilgrims climbing hills on their knees.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What balderdash is this?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I wished to prove I am a serious applicant.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Applicant for what?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: For the post of your amanuesis.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Are you mad?  42.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: That’s always a trickier question than it seems - but I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Look here, I’ve not advertised for an amanuesis!

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I know, sir, but you need one, even if you don't know it yet. The Times piece said that you're unable to compose new works because of your illness. I can't allow your music to be lost. It's far, far too precious. So I'm here to offer you my services. Ayrs wheels for a closer look at him.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: One of Mackerras’ shooting stars are you?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Frankly sir, he loathed me.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: He did, did he? Why might that be?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I called his Sixth Concerto for Flute (pauses, then:) a slave to prepubescent Saint-Saens at his most florid in the college magazine. Ayrs wheezes as if his ribs were being sawed.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He took it personally.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Oh, I’1l bet he took it personally. In the gleam that sparkles in the corner of Ayrs’ weather eyes, there is a moment of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Give me a chance sir. I promise you won't be disappointed.  43. INT. AYAR’S CHATEAU - MUSIC SALON - DAY - YEAR 1931 Frobisher sits down at the piano; sitting on the top of t piano is a ceramic statue of St. George and the Dragon. He has to move it to open the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: St. George and the Dragon. Reminds me that composing is a Crusade. Sometimes you slay the dragon. Sometimes the dragon slays you. AYRS slowly moves towards his divan, easing himself into repose.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right then... Frobisher? Frobisher, is it?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: I’ve had this little melody for viola rattling about my head for months. Let’s see if you can get it down. AYRS sits down, closes his eyes; his hand gently begins t waver. Frobisher readies his pen and blank music sheets. AYRS (CONT’D) Tar, tar... tattytattytatty-tar. Soft, simple at first: tatty tatty tar. Got it? Frobisher has no idea what he’s talking about. AYRS (CONT’D) Now it gets interesting. Tar! Tatty-tar! Quiet, hold, then--tar- tartar-tar-tar-ttttt-TAR!

dialogues.speaker: TARTARTAR
dialogues.text: Frobisher’s pen remains frozen. AYRS (CONT’D) Good. Play that back.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Uh, would love to, sir. What key are we in?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What key? B-flat of course!

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: And the time signature?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake, did you hear it or not?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I just need a little more--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: You need? My dear boy, who is working for whom here?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I apologize sir--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Are you an amanuensis or an apologist? Now pay attention. Four- eight, changing to eight-eight after the twelfth bar. If you can count that high. Frobisher stuffs his response back down his throat and ma the notations. AYRS (CONT’D) Semiquaver, B-G; semibrave A-flat- hold for four beats, no six crotchets... tar, tar, tattytattytatty, tar... F sharp, hold, then B! Okay, let me hear it. Frobisher wipes his sweating hands on his thighs. Tentatively, he begins to play. The music sounds sweet at first, Ayr’s closing his eyes b certain notes seem awkward, like teeth-breaking, un-poppe kernels in a mouthful of popcorn. AYR’S Stop. Please. You’re hurting me. You must have misheard me, I said I had a melody not a malady.  45. Across the room, Ayr’s wife, JOCASTA VAN OUTRYVE DE CROMMELYNCK (40s) enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: Vyvyan...

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Jocasta! Deliver me. Ayrs reaches for his wife and begins to climb up from his divan.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: What’s going on here? Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: This is an exercise in futility.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: I see. Should I be introduced?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: There’s really no point. The boy is as useful as the clap. Fortunately he’1l be much easier to get rid of. Leaning on his wife’s arm, he heads for the door. AYRS (CONT’D) I’m feeling rather tired. I think I shall retire early. Would you be a dear and have Hendricks see the boy out?

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: Of course. Frobisher feels his opportunity slipping away. He stares the scribbled notations; his fingers barely touch the key hovering. He closes his eyes and leaps. The music whispers across the room as gentle and intimate a lover letter. Jocasta stops to listen. Both are spell bound as he plays

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is that? It isn’t exactly what AYRS heard in his head--  46. JOCASTA (CONT’D) It’s beautiful. But it’s close enough.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: That’s it... yes, that’s it! My melody! A smile lights the corners of Frobisher’s nod.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: His name is Robert Frobisher. He is my new amanuensis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been a while. The air is stale and thin, their ski waxy with sweat. Yet, they are sitting closer and smiling

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You actually interviewed Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I guess you could say that. I hada tape recorder and asked him questions but he didn’t really answer them. He spoke in bon mots, not to you, but to the ear of posterity. He told me his best works were roller coasters. I pursued that idea. I told him I thought what was essential to his and most of Hollywood’s success was the partition or containment of the terror; so long as the Bates Motel is sealed off from our world, we want to peer in, but a film that shows us that our world IS the Bates Motel, well, that’s the stuff of Buchenwald, too dark, too depressing. We’ll dip our toes into a predatory, amoral, godless universe, but only our toes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: What bon mot did he offer to that?  47.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: (imitating Hitchcock) My dear young lady, I am a director in Hollywood. If it’s painful truth you require, go see a dentist. The old man’s laugh brightens their cell.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I saw Psycho recently again, with my niece. We loved it. He reaches into his pocket and pulls out his wallet. He shows her a picture of a young woman in a lab coat. OLD MAN (CONT’D) That’s her. Megan.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: She’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Born physicist with a better mind for mathematics than I ever had. Did her Ph.D at Cambridge. A woman at Caius! Gives you hope for the world.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Any children of your own?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: No, no... been married to science all my life I suppose. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Me neither. Never met the right person, I suppose. He puts his wallet away and mops the sweat from his foreh with a handkerchief. LUISA REY (CONT’D) God, it’s hot... She pulls her shirt up, exposing her stomach. On the side her ribs is a comet-shaped birthmark. The old man notices it and a tingle shoots up his spine.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: That’s a very... peculiar birthmark.  48.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah, my mom was sure it was going to be cancerous and kept trying to get me to remove it, but... I kinda like it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I knew someone who had a birthmark that was... similar to that.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Really? That’s pretty Twilight Zone-y? The old man nods.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Someone I cared about... very much. He looks at her intensely for a moment as if trying to se something microscopic or beneath the surface.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A hypothetical question, Ms. Rey: as a journalist, what would you pay to protect a source?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: If I believed in the issue? Any.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Prison?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: If it came to it, yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Would you be prepared to... compromise your safety?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: My father braved booby-trapped Marshes and the wrath of generals for the sake of his journalistic integrity. What kind of a mockery of his life would it be if his daughter bailed when things got a little tough?  49. The old man nods, staring at her and prepares to unburden himself of a terrible secret when-- The elevator lurches, rumbles and resumes its descent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator opens. He gestures, allowing her to step out first. Some sense of them being strangers has returned.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: It was...

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: A pleasure being trapped with you.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Let’s do it again some time. She digs in her purse for a card. LUISA REY (CONT’D) If there’s ever something I can do for you, please give me a call.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. I will. She turns to leave but something suddenly stops her.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I just realized, I don’t even know your name. He reaches out his hand to her.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Sixsmith. Dr. Rufus Sixsmith. INT. CAVENDISH’S BATHROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2009 Timothy is on his porcelain throne, reading an article on rising star of the publishing business, Timothy Cavendish There is suddenly a violent crash from outside.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What --- He barely has time to consider the sound, when the door t the bathroom explodes open. Filling the frame are three large men; Dermot’s brothers, EDDIE, MOZZA and JARVIS.  50.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Tim-o-tee Cavendish, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: MOZZA
dialogues.text: Caught with your cacks down! Cavendish, still on the toliet, tries to remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: My business hours are eleven to two. My secretary would be happy to schedule you an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Friends like us don’t need appointments.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: We like it all cozy like this. He flicks his cigarette ash on Cavendish’s thigh.

dialogues.speaker: MOZZA
dialogues.text: Visited Dermot today. He had a question for you.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Where’s our fockin’ money? Cavendish clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Boys, boys, look here. Dermot signed a copyright-transfer contract, legally the-- Jarvis grabs the toilet plunger and jams it against Cavendish’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Dermot never signed no fockin’ contract for the event of the fockin’ season! Cavendish gurgles.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Perhaps... er, ack, we might moot a provisional sum... as a basis for... on-going negotiation. Eddie taps Jarvis who releases Cavendish.  51.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okeydokey. What sum we gonna moot?

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Fifty K will do for good faith.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand pounds?!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: This is a publishing house. Do you think we just keep money lying around in shoe boxes?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We don’t give a flying fock where you get it, grandpops, just make sure you do.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Cash.

dialogues.speaker: MOZZA
dialogues.text: No bollocks. No checks.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Old fashioned money. A shoe box will do fine.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the law says---

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: The law? They burst into laughter. Eddie leans in, his smile like broken bottle.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Whad the law do for Felix Fockin Finch? Cavendish’s adam’s apple bobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish paces trying to control his panic.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATHAM
dialogues.text: I can go through it again, Mr. Cavendish but I think the total’s right: 2,343 pounds and 16 pence. That’s all that’s left.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: How is that possible?! Money was pouring in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATHAM
dialogues.text: Debts mostly, Mr. Cavendish. Solvency has its drawbacks.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: This can’t be happening.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATHAM
dialogues.text: Sir? You won’t let them take our chairs, will you? Exasperated he heads for his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inner sanctum. Cavendish stares into his wall safe, e except a small black leather book.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The situation looked dire, but I knew that Timothy Cavendish’s capital in this town could not be defined by an accountant’s balance sheet. It was high time to take stock. He lifts the little black book. Cavendish is on the phone, working his contacts. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) McCluskie! How are those delightful kiddies of yours?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: McCluskie? I need eighty thousand pounds.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Right... Mr. Cavendish, I’m afraid your performance- linked credit stream still has a twelve-month flow horizon before resizing could be feasibly optioned.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ok, How about sixty thousand? LATER: Cavendish’s fingers delicately fondle the veneer o his desk.

dialogues.speaker: KIRPAL SINGH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Charles Dickens’s desk you say?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Yes, you heard right. Charles Dickens's own, original, authentic writing desk for auction at Sotheby's with a reserve price of sixty thousand. I think that’s quite fair.

dialogues.speaker: KIRPAL SINGH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry sir, but our records indicate that the desk is already accounted for by the Dickens House museum.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ok, how about Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s desk? LATER: Another call, his phone book open to the last page front of him. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) Ah mon cher, tis “Cavendish the Ravenous,” your favourite Timothy-- The line clicks dead.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mon cher? He tosses the book in the waste paper basket. His fingers claw through his thinning hair. The office se unbearably hot and he struggles to crack open the heavily painted sash.  54. As he gulps at the air, he notices an old framed picture; young boys, dimpled smiles from another age, his older brother’s arm around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the darkness, I suddenly saw the light. Blood has always trumped water. If the Hogginses brutes wanted to turn this into a family affair, they’d find the Cavendish Clan more than ready for the task at hand. EXT. DENHOLME CAVENDISH’S PATIO - DAY DENHOLME CAVENDISH glares across his swimming pool as his brother steps down his patio.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: Oh, Satan's gonads, not again. Look, just bugger off and leave us in peace. I'll only ask you nicely once. Denholme is trawling for leaves with a big net on a pole.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you Denny. Denholme scoops a fistful of soggy leaves from the net.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: I'm not lending you a ruddy farthing until you pay back the last lot. Why must I forever be giving you handouts? No. Don't answer.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Denny, I've had a minor run-in with the wrong sort. If I can't get my hands on sixty thousand pounds, I'm going to take an awful beating.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: Get them to video it for us. Now fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I'm not joking, Denholme.  55.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: Nor am I! So, you're shoddy at being duplicitous. What of it? Why is this my problem?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: We're brothers! Don't you have a conscience?

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: Couple of Xanax and a Pimm’s cup should set me right. Cavendish crosses to his brother, hands searching for som kind of lifeline.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Help, Denny. Please. Denholme readies another volley of expletives when his wi Georgette calls from the sliding door.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Den? Who on earth are you talking to? Oh-- The three of them look at each other. An awkward silence falls like a squall.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Hello Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Uh, hello Tim. Denholme stews when suddenly a light goes on in his head. smiles and whispers to his brother.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME
dialogues.text: Alright, Tim. Sixty thousand... that’s going to take me some time. But in the interim, I know the perfect place for you to hide. INT. PAPA SONG’S GALLEY- NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Sonmi’s pod cracks open. She blinks, disoriented. The lights are still off. Yoona-939 leans in and “shhhhhs” he with a finger to her lips. She gestures for her to follow. Confused, Sonmi climbs ou of her pod and passes by all her sleeping sisters.  56. INT. PAPA SONG’S - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 The dinery is shut down, still and cold. The only small light is coming from the office. Yoona leads her towards Seer Rhee is slumped over his desk, drool glueing his chi his sony.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: He drinks Soap. Purebloods shouldn’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What happens to him when he does?

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: He giggles madly for an hour, then passes out.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What if he wakes? This is wrong, Yoona. We shouldn’t be here. Yoona lifts him by the hair.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: He never wakes up. Not without Stimulin. Like us in our pods. He’s lived with Fabricants so long, he’s nearly one of us. She drops him with a thunk.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: You wanted to know what a secret was. I am going to show you. She leads her to the back of the dinery, to a small blank wall. YOONA-939 (CONT’D) What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Nothing. Yoona pulls out the key she was playing with previously a inserts it into a small hole. A door slides open silently  57. Yoona smiles and gestures into the darkness. Nervously, Sonmi steps inside. INT. PAPA SONG’S - STORE ROOM - YEAR 2144 Yoona follows her in and the door slides shut.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: Now, sister Sonmi, you are inside a secret. A white blade slices open the dark, revealing the content the store room: shelves with silicon plants, shrink wrapp dispenser packets, forgotten coats and umbrellas. She aims the light at a section of the closet labeled “Lo and Found.” Inside a plastic box, Yoona removes an older model sony, handy device to play recordings of all kind.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: A sony? We’re not allowed--

dialogues.speaker: YOONA-939
dialogues.text: Hush, sister. No one will ever know. She sits and beckons Sonmi as Eve tempted with fruit. Son sits bedside her. Yoona hits a button and a semi-3d image appears. It isa scene from a film. An older ACTOR who bears a small resemblance to Timothy Cavendish rises proudly and announ

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH LOOK-A-LIKE
dialogues.text: This is a violation of the ruddy Incarceration Act! I will not be subjugated to criminal abuse! He storms out of the white, hospital-like room, throwing the doors and as he exits-- The image blooms as if suddenly over-exposed, then freeze for a moment before repeating. The two Fabricants stare at the secret image and as it pl again, Yoona mouths the words with the actor.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you report Yoona-939 to Seer Rhee the next day?  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orison spinning is the only sound as Sonmi considers answer.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I couldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Because she trusted me.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: But your actions violated the Fifth Catechism.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s true.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: How did you justify this transgression?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: She was my friend. Her answer surprises him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize Fabricants had friends.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: There is much that Purebloods do not realize about Fabricants. Isn’t that the reason I am here? He squirms a bit and then continues.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Please describe the events of March 23rd from your perspective.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I was wiping tables along the vidy- bay. I had a clear view of the elevator bank.  59. INT. PAPA SONG’S - DAY - YEAR 2144 Sonmi is cleaning her tables. Across the dinery, Yoona is serving a screaming party of children. Sonmi watches as Yoona stops smiling. Her mouth begins mouthing the words from the video; “I will not be subjuga to criminal abuse.” Suddenly she lifts one of the children and runs out of th dinery. Pandemonium, screaming, crowds fleeing from her path, enforcers radioing for help; all seen through the surreal silence behind the window, the sound blocked by the plexi Yoona uses the child’s hand to call the elevator. They ge in and the door closes. Emotion floods into her, as Sonmi tries to hold onto her fading smile. From a distance, we can hear the muffled sound of gunfire The parent of the child continues screaming until the elevator returns. An Enforcer hands the child to the parent. Yoona’s bloody body lays on the floor. Sonmi continues wiping even though she cannot look away, unbearable sadness, like a secret behind her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
