dialogues.text: It was my first experience of death. INT. AYRS’ ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 We drift towards Ayrs’ body; we cannot tell whether he is alive or dead. Frobisher stands beside the bed, staring with a confused expression at the object in his hand-- A Luger pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the bound hands of the young man being whipped.  60. He looks up and reaches towards us as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa Rey drives her Volkswagen as fast as it can go away from Swannekke Island. A blue sedan that looks like an unmarked police car, pull along side her. She sees the man driving the car only for an instant befo he swerves into her-- Slamming her car through the guardrail and flying out ove the edge. INT. BAILEY DWELLING - ZACHRY’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2321 Zachry bolts awake, scared out of his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry pounds on the door until the Abbess opens it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Zachry Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: A dream, Abbess. Sorrysome for wakin’you but I know somethin’ diresome’s gon’a’ppen.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbess sways, her eyes closed, holding onto Zachry’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Tis true, Old Georgie’s a’hungerin’ for your soul. Zachry whimpers.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He spit a cuss on your dreams.  61.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I know’d it, ohhh, I know’d it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: But Sonmi can protect you.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Sonmi?!

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: She cares for all her flock. But you got to mind her warnin’.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What warnin’? The Abbess channels the voice of their protector.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: “Enemy’s sleepin’, don’t slit that throat. Hands’a’bleedin’, mus’nt let go. Bridge a’burnin’, your path lies below.” Her body sags, weak from the effort.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: An augurin’...

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Trust Sonmi, Zachry. Keep her warnin’ with you, nail it to your mem’ry and She will protect you. Zachry mouths the words, trying to memorize them. INT. PAPA SONG’S GALLEY - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Colored gas swirls wake Sonmi-451 in her pod. All the oth clones stay asleep. The door is cracked open, glowing amber light spilling in the galley. Sonmi climbs out of her bed, drawn to the noi from the main room. INT. PAPA SONG’S - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Her bare feet step timidly towards the office. Peering through the open door, she sees Seer Rhee sprawled on the floor, blood and mucus draining from his nose. Next to hi an overturned box of Soap.  62. A man in his thirties, dressed in black, is going through digital files. His name is CHANG.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Hello Sonmi-451. There is no reason to hide. Sonmi nervously steps out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Chang.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What has happened to Seer Rhee?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Officially-- Soap overdose. Nothing more pathetic than a Pureblood hooked on Soap. He picks up the box of Soap.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s unfortunate that it had to happen now with everything going so well because it’s probable that the Enforcers and the DNA sniffers will find out about you, about your midnight strolls, your connection to Yoona-939 and possibly even the un-sanctioned thoughts that have been going on in your head. If they do, you will be decommissioned. Sonmi experiences her first real taste of fear. CHANG (CONT’D) Your choice: you can remain here, suffer the consequences of your probable discovery or you can come with me.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why did you go with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archivist checks his sony-file.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Fear.  63.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Fear of what?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I knew that if I didn’t do something soon, what had happened to Yoona was going to happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship has set its sails and is leaving the island behi

dialogues.speaker: EWING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Friday the 15th. We made sail with the morning tide. INT. THE PROPHETESS - ADAM EWING’S CABIN - DAY - YEAR 184 Pale-faced and sweating, Ewing is writing, his journal po awkwardly on his knees in bed while a few men deposit bar of sundry provisions and a bolt of sailcloth in his room.

dialogues.speaker: EWING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Boerhaave had my cabin changed. I have been quarantined to a storeroom away from the other passengers and crew. Henry argued in vain that the Polynesian Worm is not contagious. Hardly matters. All I want to do right now, is sleep. A young sailor, RAPHAEL, throws another barrel in front o Ewing to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHAEL
dialogues.text: Apologies, Mr. Ewing, it’s by order of Mr. Boerhaave. No other space left for late deliveries, he said.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: I know... it’s not your fault, Raphael.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHAEL
dialogues.text: You don’t look well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Your concern is much appreciated.  64. INT. FROBISHER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 Frobisher soaks in his bed, swathed in silk sheets and do stuffed duvets reading a book and enjoying a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sixsmith. Received your post yesterday. Really, old boy, your concern couldn’t be more misplaced. Did I not tell you I had a Plan? The book is “The Pacific Journal of Adam Ewing.” INT. AYR’S CHATEAU - MUSIC ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1931 Ayr’s reclines on his divan conducting with a cigarette a Frobisher tries to play the piano while scribbling notes. The voices and music are heard beneath the voice-over.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is it not miraculous how one’s fortune can turn so quickly, so completely? One moment, leaping from a hotel window, the next, gainfully employed by one of the world’s greatest living composers.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Semiquaver, B-G, semibreve, A-flat, hold it for four beats-- no six crochets!

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Then, F sharp and B, yes?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! Tar-tatty-tatty-tarrrrr. Now, now Frobisher, the clarinet is the concubine, the violas are yew trees in the cemetery and the clavichord is the moon... A minor, sixteenth bar floating onwards...

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ayrs is one of the few composers I want my own creativity informed by. Musicologically he is Janus-headed. Watching him use counterpoint and mix colors is exhilarating but not nearly as much as when he stops to ask my opinion. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: More than a few of my suggestions have been incorporated. Quite sobering. Mark my words, Sixsmith, people in the future will be studying this music. Frobisher’s quill flies as the music is created between t INT. FROBISHER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 Frobisher is out of bed, frustrated, digging through the bookshelves.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Must try to get some sleep. You know how music stimulates me. Trying to be a good boy. Rutting my way through the bedroom bookshelves. Your fevered cockswain. On the bed is the open book which we see has been torn in half.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: P.S. Got hooked into a journal written by a dying lawyer on a voyage from a Pacific Isle to San Francisco around the time of the gold rush. The author, Adam Ewing puts me in mind of Melville’s bumbler Captain Delano, blind to all conspirators- he has a friend, a trusty Dr. Goose who he hasn’t spotted is obviously a vampire, fueling his hypochondria in order to poison him for his money. The second half of the book is nowhere to be found. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) To my great annoyance, the pages cease, mid-sentence. Half the book is missing. Searched high and low. No luck. It’s completely killing me. Could you be a mensch and when you’re next foraging at the Ottos’s Book’s, make an inquiry?  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rufus Sixsmith sits on the bedside of his hotel room to a stack of old envelopes. He has randomly chosen one o the letters his love wrote him over 40 years ago.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A half-finished book is, after all, a half-finished love affair. Close on the television where a news conference is being broadcast of Swannekke Island. ALBERTO GRIMALDI, CEO of t nuclear power based company Seaboard, addresses an audien

dialogues.speaker: GRIMALDI, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Our great nation suffers from a debilitating addiction and its name is oil. Sixsmith looks up to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: GRIMALDI, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: In confronting this problem, some bury their heads in the sand, some fantasize about wind turbines and (smiles wryly) pig gas. (audience chuckles) But I am here today to tell you that the cure for oil is right here, right now, on Swannekke Island. On the bed, next to the letters, is a thick bound report entitled: “The HYDRA-Zero Reactor -- An Operational Assessment Model -- Project Head Dr. Rufus Sixsmith -- Unauthorized Possession is a Federal Crime Under the Mili and Industrial Espionage Act.” Sixsmith shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH
dialogues.text: And when the hydrogen buildup blows the roof off the containment center? When prevailing winds shower radiation all across California? As if in response, the telephone rings. SIXSMITH (CONT’D) Megan? A brusque male voice answers.  67.

dialogues.speaker: DEEP VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They’re coming.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: DEEP VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They traced your last call to this hotel. Get out of there now. They are going to kill you. The words suck the air form his lungs. DEEP VOICE (0.S.) (CONT’D) You’ve got twenty minutes, max. Dial tone, a droning eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith is at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH
dialogues.text: It’s terribly important that I leave tonight.

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: I’m sure it is, sir but we got an air-traffic-control strike and acres of stranded passengers. Tomorrow is the best I can do.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH
dialogues.text: All right... I understand. Thank you. He turns away, visibly shaken. He pulls his handkerchief from his pocket and when he does he finds --- Luisa Rey’s card. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 In the dark, a phone begins to ring. Luisa reaches for th alarm but when it doesn’t stop, the fog of sleep lifts an she grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Hello?  She hauls 68.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello Ms. Rey. I am frightfully sorry for calling at this hour. I started writing a letter but the only address I have is your magazine and I was worried it might not reach you.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Dr. Sixsmith?

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know it seems absurd that we just met- in an elevator, for God’s sake, but I have this feeling that I have known you much longer.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Airport Sheraton. herself out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’m on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midland landscape rushes past the window. Cavendish final relaxes aboard a train.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew I could count on Dennie. A safe place to lay low was exactly what I needed. Soon after the initial exhilaration of a journey begun, I felt my guard begin to drop. He is reading a manuscript for a novel, entitled: “Half- Lives, A Luisa Rey Mystery” by JAVIER GOMEZ.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was while reading a new submission, a surprisingly clever little young-hack-takes-on- corporate-corruption ditty, when a powerful deja vu ran through my bones.  69. He stares out the window. The landscape evokes forgotten feelings inside Cavendish.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had been here before; a train just like this one gliding past the same smear of landscape. Suddenly I was no longer Cavendish the elder, Squanderer of Life but... Cavendish sees another reflection in the window: the came moves revealing a 19-YEAR-OLD CAVENDISH, insecure, red cheeked, nervously waiting for the train to reach the upcoming station.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. a young virile, bohemian, on a train to Little Chesterford, a single thought, like a scratched record, turning over and over in his mind; “Ursula.” The sign for “Little Chesterford Station” crawls past his window; the sound of the braking train, like a siren call Young Cavendish gets up, jumps out of the train. From inside the train, Old Cavendish sees his former self hurry through the station towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You would think a place the size of England could easily hold all the happenings in one humble lifetime without much overlap, I mean, it's not ruddy Luxembourg we live in, but no, we cross, criss-cross and recross our old tracks like figure skaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train pulls away revealing Cavendish looking like som caught between lost and found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish steps outside the train station, sees Young Cavendish shyly enter an old Citroen. Inside, YOUNG URSUL greets him with a smile.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The love of my life? I could think of no other serious applicants. What had happened to her? And more importantly, what had happened to the young man who had ridden this same train composing sonnets to his “Goddess Divine.” INT. PAPA SONG’S ELEVATOR - DAY - YEAR 2144 Sonmi and Chang are ascending, the elevator bearing them towards the city’s surface. Sonmi is very quiet. In her hand is the broken sony. She carries it like a chi clutching a precious, stuffed animal.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What were you feeling at that particular moment? Just as the elevator door opened?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: It was... exhilarating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open and Sonmi follows Chang out into the conur It is a sprawling urban canopy; ADV screens hover and cov almost every inch of open space. Transit tubes network gnarled strato-scrapers. Sunpoles b light, umbrellas radiating logos through the mist, Purebl hunched over their portables. It is an impossible amount of information and Sonmi looks about to get sick. Chang takes her by the arm and steadie her into the Elite-tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private transport tube. Chang presses his “soul” thumb the controls and keys in the destination code. Sonmi sits as the car hums, quickly picking up speed, ban through the rivers of electric light.  71. They dive down and travel for a moment underwater before shooting up and weaving through older buildings, a part o the lower root structure to the towering spires rising ab them. After a moment, they seem to clear an edge of the city an the distance Sonmi sees an actual mountain; the sun rinsi just behind it.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Are you all right? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: My first sunrise. It is the first time we see her smile in a way that does seem like a mask. She looks at the sony in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Can I ask where you got that?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Yoona shared it with me. I couldn’t leave it behind.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: You’re not supposed to have a sony.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I’m not supposed to leave Papa-Song and yet here I am. He smiles, already liking her.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Can I have a look? She hesitates and then hands it to him. He starts it and watches the loop of the Cavendish story. CHANG (CONT’D) It’s an old disney. But where’s the rest of it?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: The rest of it? He examines the device.  72.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: This thing used to play vidies. They’re stories. But its chip is corrupt. If you wanted I could digi it and get you a complete copy? That way at least we’d know if it was a happy or a sad ending. If you wanted. Tentatively, she nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish wanders the tree lined village.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Drunk on nostalgia I found myself ignoring the warnings of Madame Bovary and plunging into some kind of romantic trance. He passes a building and peeks through the large glass windows. Inside: a 50’s cafeteria where Young Cavendish a Ursula are having breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There was the cafe where we drank milky tea in dirty mugs, eating toast, watery eggs and canned tomatoes but be honest, Cavendish, was any other breakfast in your life so delectable? Back to present: the cafe is now a fitness club.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The world curdles from its room temperature taste. Cavendish continues his walk through the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful mansion nestled in a grove of ancient oak tre

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Before I realized it, my feet had born me back, back to Dockery House, to the Temple of Sacrifice, where I offered up my virginity. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Back to those four days of paradise when Ursula’s mater and pater slipped off to Greece for a long weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teenaged Cavendish, his chin dappled more with fuzz than whiskers, wearing only his socks and a duvet, returns to bedroom having raided daddy’s liquor cabinet. On his calf, just below the back of his knee, we notice a comet-shaped birthmark. His nubile love lays on the bed re-reading the sonnet he wrote. He climbs back into bed, their bodies drawn to each other warmth as she suckles the whiskey from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or so we thought. Mater stands frozen in horror as Cavendish mounts her daughter. Pater arrives as the two young bodies begin to undulate. URSULA’S PATER

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Calamity. Cavendish leaps away from her as if she was poi oak. Bare-assed, he slips in his socks, stumbles over a table, falls-- Sees a cat, grabs it to hide his family jewels as he impl the parents.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Sir! Madame! I assure you this is completely innocent-- The cat scratches at his tender, dangly bits and Timothy screams, throws the cat in the air as he slips backward a Crashes out the large picture window.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two sprained ankles. One cracked rib. Official cause of accident listed on the hospital form: Young Timothy lies sprawled in the garden bushes.  74.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The older Cavendish creeps up to the house, towards that window, and peers inside the room lit electric marigold.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why had I never returned her calls or letters? Shame. Ignominious retreat. Spinelessness. Hallmarks of the Cavendish Clan. He watches as a mother repairs a broken broomstick for he child dressed as a witch.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew I had no business going back there. I knew the chances that she still lived in that house were practically zilch and yet-- Suddenly an older woman dressed as a devil, enters the domestic frieze and Cavendish’s eyes lite up.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There she was. Ursula. My first real regret, like a first cigarette, that began a lifelong addiction. Ursula says something to her daughter and grandchild, and they giggle. Cavendish cannot help but giggle too, even though he didn’t hear a thing. His eyes go teary.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why was I standing out here in the cold, cowering in the shadows? Why was I not in that room lit electric marigold? I realized I had the choice: I could slink off and return to the station and continue as planned or I could go boldly to the door, knock without fear of potential consequence and discover what hope, if any, lay within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards her broken sony.  He shrugs. He smiles. 75.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Are endings always “happy or sad?”

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Usually. Most people like ‘em simple.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: But not you?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: I like all of it: happy, sad and everything in between with a creamy scoop of sex served a la mode. She clutches her sony and edges away from him. The tube banks, shifting into a different line which is n headed str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym an tooth of a clouds. Truman rub: aight at a mountain.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There it is.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: University. Your new home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: d Truman Napes stare out at Mauna Kea, a jagged mountain sunk into the underbelly of low lying s his beard then gestures with his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Won’t get me up that diresome spire. My gran'pa's pa named Truman Third went scavvin’ for Old-Un gear up there. He looks at Meronym. TRUMAN (CONT’D) Whoa they found a wondersome ironstone temple, yay, but they also found Old Georgie a’waitin’.  76.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an ancient ruin, Old Georgie glowers over a man who screams in terror.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: The Weak are Meat and the Strong do Eat. Old Georgie brandishes a spoon and scoops out the man’s e and pops it in his mouth. The devil cackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry is hiding in some brush, spying on Meronym and Tru Napes while Old Georgie whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: That Prescient’s got a curio to kill a cart-full o’cats ‘n then some. Zachry watches Meronym and Truman Napes, gesturing with h pipe, talking about what happened atop Mauna Kea. Zachry’s eyes narrow as he crawls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbess is tending the icons. JZachry tries to remain in a proper reverential position but he is too wound up.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: She’s plannin’ on trekin’ up Mauna Kea even though it’s forbidden.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Now I’m warnin’ you Zachry Bailey, makin’ ‘cusations ‘gainst a spesh guest jus’ ain’t politsome.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: She up’ta somthin’ Abbess. She been schemin’ an’ secretin’ at night. I seen it!  77.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: ‘Nough’s enough. You bring me ev’dence Meronym’s plannin’ to kill us in our sleep, I’ll calla gatherin’. If you ain’t got no ev’dence, you best hold that tongue. Suddenly, there is a urgent knock on the door. ABBESS (CONT’D) Sakes‘live, what now? She opens the door to a young girl.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Abbess, you gotta come quick! It’s the Bailey girl! Zachry hears his niece’s name and rushes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Catkin?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Aye. She's dyin. INT. ADAM EWING’S CABIN - PROPHETESS - NIGHT Lying on his tiny bed, his body shakes from the pain, and Ewing awakes from a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: EWING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My Parasite writhes at night, like a new babe's finger igniting spasms of pain while visions and voices, obscene and monstrous, haunt me. On his knees, Adam Ewing prays into his clasped hands by candlelight, his shoulders hunched as if pressed down by unseen force. The flame strobes against a ubiquitous draf causing shadows to leap around the cramped cabin. He is pale, a sheen of sweat covers his waxy face. Finish he crosses himself and blows out the candle. He’s asleep again. In blackness, we hear a voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing? Mr. Ewing? Startled, Ewing awakes, hitting his head on the bulkhead.  78. He peers into the dark, a shaft of moonlight washing thro the porthole. Slowly a serpentine length of hawser uncoil and he sees a black form rise like a djin.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: In the name of God---

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing, do not fear- Mr. Ewing- no harm, no shout, please, sir. He leaps to Ewing’s bedside, a powerful hand sealing his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Help! Help mmph--

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing, no harm, you safe, I friend of Mr. D'Arnog- you know he Christian- please, quiet! Ewing nods, though he is obviously still afraid. Slowly t man releases Ewing’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: My name is Autua. You know I, you seen I, aye- you pity I.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: What do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Maori whip I- you seen. The image of the Moriori being flogged by the "Lizard Kin suddenly flashes in Ewing’s head and he nods. AUTUA (CONT’D) You good man- Mr. D'Arnog tell you good man- he hid I in your cabin yesterday night- I escape- you help, Mr. Ewing. Ewing bristles at the thought of D’Arnog. AUTUA (CONT’D) If you no help- I in trouble dead.  79.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: You're already very much "in trouble dead." The Prophetess is a mercantile vessel, not an “underground railroad" for escaping slaves. Autua straightens in pride.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: I able seaman! I earn passage!

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Then I suggest you surrender to the captain's mercies forthwith.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: No! They no listen I! Swim away home, Nigger, they say and throw I in drink! You lawman aye? You go, you talk, I stay, I hide! Please. Cap'n hear you, Mr. Ewing. Please. Ewing shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: No. I can’t help you. Whatever D’Arnog told you about me, I assure you, he is quite mistaken. I’m afraid your fate is your own. I desire no part in it. Autua’s voice softens to a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Then kill I. His hand finds Ewing’s and he closes their fingers around hilt of a dagger. AUTUA (CONT’D) Say to others I attack you, so you kill I.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: You no help I, you kill I, just same. It's true, you know it. I ain't be fish food, Mr. Ewing. With a terrible calmness and certitude Autua presses its against his own throat.  80.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: You’re mad.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: I not mad. Die here is better. Do it. Do it quick. Ewing swallows hard as a ringing begins to rise in his ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith wakes to the ringing telephone.

dialogues.speaker: SIXSMITH
dialogues.text: Luisa? God, I must have dozed off. Terrible dream. Thank you for coming. I’m in 1404. He hangs up when, behind him, outside on the balcony-- A shadow drops from the floor above. He reaches for the report as A MAN slides open the door. Sixsmith turns just as the man steps close and places a g to the scientist’s temple and-- Pulls the trigger. Blood splatters the wall, the lamp shade and a half-finis letter to Luisa lying on the desk. Sixsmith’ body drops backwards onto the bed, burying Frobisher’s letters under his back. The assassin looks around. He is a man whose most distinguishing attribute is that there's nothing distinguishing about him. His name is BILL SMOKE. Smoke notices the report and the letter to Luisa when the is a knock at the door. Silently, he creeps to the door as the knocking continues He looks through the peep-hole and sees Luisa.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: (through the door)Dr. Sixsmith? It’s Luisa. Dr. Sixsmith? Smoke puts the barrel with its long silencer against the door, aiming straight at her until-- She leaves.  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa leads the MANAGER to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: He wasn’t looking that well the last time I saw him and I’m just worried that something happened-- The elevator opens, revealing Bill Smoke. As Smoke passes them, he looks at Luisa and in the look t is something that reminds us of the look Old Georgie gave Zachry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager opens the door and Luisa follows him in.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Oh my god-- Luisa covers her mouth. Sixsmith lays awkwardly on the be blood Pollock-ing the wall, the gun Smoke used, now in Sixsmith’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Go! Call the police! Hurry! The manager rushes out while Luisa quickly scans the room The report and the letter are gone. The room seems completely clean, until, coming up from looking under the bed, she notices a tiny bit of aged pap underneath Sixsmith’s back. She softly pushes him to the side and reveals the thick p of letters.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My Dear Sixsmith, How I wish you were here with me now. INT. AYRS’ CHATEAU, SCARLET ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1931 TADEUSZ AUGUSTOWSKI, the Polish conductor and colleague o Ayrs is reading “Der Todtenvogel,” Ayrs and Frobisher’s latest collaboration.  82.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today Ayrs and I presented our first collaboration, a short tone poem called "Der Todtenvogel", to Tadeusz Augustowski, Ayrs’ favourite conductor. It’s an intriguing animal. It borrows resonances from Wagner's Ring, then disintegrates the theme into a Stravinskyesque nightmare policed by Sibelian wraiths. Horrible, delectable, wish you could hear it. Augustowski sways gently to the music in his head, hand lightly bobbing in the air as if floating on an invisible current.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's the most accomplished tone poem I know of written since the war and I tell you, Sixsmith, that more than a few of its best ideas are mine. Suppose an amanuensis must reconcile himself to renouncing his share in authorship, though Vyvyan recently referred to our work as a “partnership.” Frobisher and Ayrs subtly watch in expectation. Augustows monocle falls from his eye socket. He turns to Ayrs.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTOWSKI
dialogues.text: A man at our time of life, Ayrs-- has no right to such daring ideas. Where are you getting ‘em from? Ayrs puffs himself up.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: I suppose I've won a rearguard action or two in my war against decrepitude. My boy Robert here is proving a valuable aide-de-camp. Frobisher smiles, lifting a tea pot.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: More tea? INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 Luisa is smoking a joint, reading Frobisher’s letters. He apartment is cramped, cluttered but comfortable.  83. On one of the brick and board bookshelves we see a pictur her father, Lester Rey. Behind her, a shadow drops from the balcony above. As she reads, the shadow creeps up behind her until movin around the couch-- Luisa’s scream catches in her throat-- As she sees JAVIER GOMEZ, her teenage friend.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Jesus... Javier Gomez what did I tell you about jumping across balconies? What if someone reports you as a burglar? What if you fell?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Why do you leave your door open if you don’t want me to come in?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Because, Smarty-pants the only thing worse than having you jump onto my balcony, is the idea of you jumping onto my balcony and then being stuck out there. She notices the welt across his face. LUISA REY (CONT’D) Wolfman?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Doesn’t hurt. Luisa reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’m calling your mother. She has to know what kind of ass-hole she’s dating. Javier watches her dialing.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: She knows. They look at each other. Reluctantly, she replaces the receiver.  84.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: You know we can’t let this go on.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (pointing at the letters) What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Don’t try to ignore me.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I know you wanna help but if you call her, she’ll leave work and there’ll be a big fight and he’1l smash more stuff and hit me harder next time. The truth, spoken without emotion or eye-contact, sits li stone wall separating them.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIER
dialogues.text: What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Just... old letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wee hours of the morning, the warmth of the house radiates against the Magritte night-scape. A cab arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Past calls to us with the enchantment of a Siren, luring us into dangerous waters. Better, I believed, to fill one’s ears with beeswax and stay the course. Cavendish empties his wallet to the cab driver. Hunched o from the long ride he climbs the stairs and rings the bel The door opens. A smiling angel of a woman welcomes him i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She helps him inside.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA ANGEL
dialogues.text: Was your trip difficult?  85.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ohh, you’ve no idea. Hellish. Made a terrible mistake and got off the train. Didn’t know it was the last one. Missed the only bus. Finally took a cab. Driver talked the entire way. Too ruddy awful for words.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA ANGEL
dialogues.text: The only thing that matters is that you've arrived safely.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I had to use the last of my money--

dialogues.speaker: AURORA ANGEL
dialogues.text: All you need to worry about, Mr. Cavendish, is getting a good night’s sleep. He makes a noise like a baby, overcome with a wave of pleasure. AURORA ANGEL (CONT’D) Just sign right here. We’ve gota beautiful room with a garden view. You'll love it. He signs in. AURORA ANGEL (CONT’D) Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is modern, clean with soft lighting in sleepy corners. The bed is trimmed with crisp sheets. Cavendish looks like he might cry.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Bliss, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA ANGEL
dialogues.text: Sweet dreams, then.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Hoggins Horrors were long gone and I was scot free while Denny, dearest Denholme was footing the bill. Couldn’t be more perfect. And tomorrow, life could begin afresh, afresh, afresh!  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The University is cut into the side of the mountain. Chang leads Sonmi through the concourse with students. Ma of them look at her uniform or her awkwardness and giggle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang leads down the throat of a utilitarian hall. At the end, there Sonmi is a door, the digital name plate slight crooked, “BOOM-SOOK, KIM.” Chang knocks, then lets himself in. INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - DAY - YEAR 2144 A cramped, dirty sty, rancid with pureblood male odor. Bi are overflowing, a crossbow target hangs by the door. A single filthy window opens into a featureless courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Wait here, for Mr. Kim. Obey him as you would a Seer. He places the box of Soap in the fridge. CHANG (CONT’D) Keep your food refrigerated (indicating the sony) Make sure you keep that hidden. I’ll be back in a few days to check on you.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Why... are you doing this? He considers his answer carefully.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Because I care about what happens to you. The words sound like a foreign language to her. He smiles again and slips out the door leaving her to a completely new life.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did you know he was Union?  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The memory remains sweet to her.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: No. But it wouldn’t have mattered.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Because it was the first time a Pureblood had showed me a kindness. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1846 Ewing returns to his room. It appears empty. He slips one of the barrels in front of the door, blocking it.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Come on, then. The wiry man slides out from the darkness of his hiding place, a wide smile across his face when he sees Ewing pu food from his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Ohhh, thank ya’ missa Ewing. Missa D’Anrnog right about you.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Don’t mention that mongrel’s name again. To tell the truth, I was worried you might try to eat me if you didn’t get something in that stomach.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: You safe, missa Ewing. I no like white meat. Autua smiles, gobbling the stale bread and cheese.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Before I decide what I am going to do with you, tell me why you were being whipped so savagely. A long silence filled only with the sound of Autua’s smac lips.  88.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: My uncle was a sailor. Took me on a French whaler when I was ten year old. I seen too much’a the world. I no good slave.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Why did you look at me?

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Pain strong, aye, but friend’s eyes more strong.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: You're a runaway slave. I’ma lawyer. How do you imagine we could possibly be friends. He keeps chewing and smiling as jabs his finger from his to Ewing’s.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Here all you need. INT. AYR’S CHATEAU - MUSIC ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 A study of anticipation as they wait for Jocasta to open telegram.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Telegram arrived with reviews of “Todtenvogel.”

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: Before I open this, Vyvyan, I need you to promise me--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Please, Jocasta, I am too old to worry about what a bunch of parasitic half-wits think of my Music. Just read the damn thing and then consign it to the fire. Unconvinced, she peels open the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: First Performance Mystified Stop. Ayrs rubs the whiskers around his tightening lips.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Second Performance Fisticuffs Stop.  89. Frobisher’s eyebrow arches in anticipation. JOCASTA (CONT’D) Third Performance Adored Stop Fourth Rose Petals Thrown Beneath Your Feet Stop You Are Toast Of Town Congratulations Stop. She is almost unable to finish it for the joy bubbling ou her. Frobisher can’t feel his feet on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Well... even a broken clock is right twice a day. A smile spreads.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jocasta, open a bottle of the ‘08 Pinot Rouge. I make it a point to never be toasted without a drink in my hand. She leaves, her own smile flashing at Frobisher like a peeking garter-belt. The two artists are left alone, their expression a reflec of each other.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At that moment Sixsmith, when he looked at me, I saw something in his ice-blue eyes, something beneath all the years and the illness. Something familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher is pushing Ayrs wheelchair. The wind urges the dried leaves to dance.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The following morning I pushed his chair down the Monk’s walk. Autumn leaves gusted around in urgent spirals as if V.A. was the sorcerer and I his apprentice. He unveiled his concept for a new piece based on his beloved Nietzsche’s “Eternal Recurrence.” Wants my services for another year. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Told him I would think about it. Obviously upset him that I didn’t give a breathy “yes!” On the spot. I want the old bugger to admit he needs me. P.S. Best news of all. I’ve started my own work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa Rey enters the store and is immediately halted. The music playing takes her breath away; it’s spectral, hypno and... intimately familiar.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I know this music. What the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, it’s a customer order. Not for sale. I shouldn’t really be playing it. She puts her purse on the counter and digs out her wallet

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: All right. My name’s Luisa Rey, I phoned about an obscure recording by Robert Frobisher. Someone said they found it. The clerk smiles guiltily. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Ooops. Busted. I thought I should check it to make sure it wasn’t scratched but to be totally honest, I can’t stop listening to it.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: This is “The Cloud Atlas Sextet"?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Why companies won’t finance recordings of lost gems like this, it’s criminal.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Where have I heard it before?  91.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Can't be more than a handful in North America.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: But I know it. I know I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at one another, across the table.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: He told me, “Knowledge is to consciousness what sunlight is to plants.”

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: So it was Chang that supplied you with the codes to the Boom-Sook Kim’s Unity terminal?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: During the day, I did whatever chores he told me to do, but at night... INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Boom-Sook is passed out, bathed in the flickering flesh-t light of his slasher porno.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At night I was free. Sonmi finishes folding his laundry. She checks to make su he is sleeping, then quietly moves to the Unity terminal. SONMI-451 (V.O.) (CONT’D) I traveled the length, breadth and width of your culture; from the philosophy of the Greeks to poetry of the Chinese, from the unending histories of your constant wars to the Seven Dialects of Jong Il. The sony display shows all sorts of written material as w as hyper-linked graphics, antique sketches, paintings etc  92.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The library often refused my requested downloads, but this made me understand that the path I was on was the correct one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archivist is disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Mr. Kim had no awareness of what was truly happening? Sonmi shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Of course not. He believed he was developing a formula for a more attentive domestic.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: While in reality, Union pursued their agenda.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Their goal was always the Ascendency of a Fabricant. Yoona had failed. I was their last remaining hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catkin lays on her small bed, surrounded by family and neighbors. Her face is swollen and sweaty. The HERBALIST dips a rag into cool water and dabs it to her forehead. Zachry and the Abbess push through the crowd into the roo

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS
dialogues.text: Oh Sonmi. She knows the child is near death. JZachry embraces his sister Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Leary the healer says she’1l be gone by sundown so better’n say our goodbyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It ain’t right, ain’t fair but nuthin to be done... Zachry looks at Catkin, knowing what Rose believes is not True-true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry rushes through the woods. Rain slashes across his face making his tears invisible. He bursts into a clearing where he finds what he has been looking for: Meronym. She is taking water samples, collecting them in small gla jars.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Catkin’s dyin’! She stands.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Trod on a scorpion fish. The energy seeps out of her as she realizes what will hap to the young girl. It seems terribly unfair.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can save her! She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got spesh smart in that gearbag what'll save her! That’s the True- true! Her expression hardens. She throws her bag on the ground between them.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: How you know what’s in my gearbag? More sneakin’n’spyin? Why not jus’ thief the spesh smart yourself? Zachry is stunned and ashamed.  94.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: ...It were a mistake, what I done while you guestin’ at our home. I didn’t trust.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Why trust now?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I got no choice. Catkin’s still’n’stiff as stone. You’re my only hope. It hurts but Meronym remains resolved.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: The life o’ your tribe’s got a nat’ral order. Catkin’d trod on that scorpion fish if I’d been here or not.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I’m jus a stoopit goat herder but I reck’n jus’ by bein’ here you’re bustin’ this nat’ral order! I reck’n you're killin’ Catkin by not actin’!

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I ain’t here to play Lady Sonmi ev'ry time sumthn’ bad happ’ns an click my fingers’n’ make it right!

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: If it were a Prescient that were layin with poison meltin’ her heart’n’lungs? If it were your kin? They both know the answer to that question.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why’s a Precient’s life worth more’n a Valleysman?! Zachry’s eyes harden.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l take you to Mauna Kea! The rain beats against Meronym’s poncho.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ev’one knows my soul is stoned. Don’t matta’ what devils waitin’ for me up there. They goin’ have me one day an’ways. You save Catkin’n I’ll take you an’where you wanna go. A dozen arguments blow through her mind but she sets her against everyone of them. She bends down and tears through her gearbag, mumbling to herself, swearing in a language Zachry can’t understand. Grabbing something she stands.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: All right. Here’s the deal. You sneak this in Catkin’s mouth so slywise no un’see, nay, nor even thinkied they seen and for Sonmi’s sake if Catkin lives, you make sure the herb’list gets the hooray- hooray, not that voodoo snake oilster from Hilo. Yay? Gratitude bubbles out of every pore.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Yay... Yay! He takes the small turquoise stone from her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank’ya, thank’ya, Sonmi bless’ya--

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Stop your yibberin’n go. Go! He bolts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orison hums.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: How long did you serve Mr. Boom- Sook Kim as a domestic?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Until twelfth-month. I remember watching the snow fall, through the small dorm window.  96. INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 The room is clean and tidy now. Sonmi is cleaning the one window, while Boom-Sook plays an action porn game with hi Game toy. Outside fat snow flakes fall lazily.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was like nothing I had ever seen: bruised lilac in half-lite. Such pure solace.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You speak like an aesthete sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Perhaps those deprived of beauty perceive it most instinctively. INT. CAVENDISH’S ROOM, AURORA HOUSE - DAY - YEAR 2009 Cavendish awakes to the sound of rustling fabric. A middle aged WOMAN with a dour pageboy haircut is riflin through his belongings.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What the-- Cavendish snaps to focus. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) What the ruddy hell are you doing in my room, you pilfering warty sow? She roots through the pockets of his coat.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Because you are new, I will not have you eat soap powder. This time. Be warned, I do not stand for offensive language in Aurora House. Not from anyone. And I never make idle threats, Mr. Cavendish. Never.  97.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I'll ruddy well talk to you how I ruddy well like, you stinking ruddy thief! Make me eat soap powder? I'd like to see you try! Let's call Hotel Security! Let's call the police! You ask about offensive language, and I'll ask about breaking, entry and theft! She quickly crosses to his bed and slaps him hard across chops. Cavendish, falls back onto his pillow, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Tsk. A disappointing start. I am Mrs. Noakes. You do not wish to cross me.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Is this some sort of a kinky S &M hotel? MRS. NOAKES returns to his things.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOAKES
dialogues.text: Smoking is discouraged here. I will have to confiscate these cigars. The lighter is far too dangerous for you to play with. And what, pray, are these? She dangles his keys. MRS. NOAKES (CONT’D) Keys go walkies! Let's give them to Mrs. Judd for safekeeping, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Let's not give them to anyone, you crazy dragon! You strike me! You rob me! What kind of ruddy hotel hires thieves for chambermaids? She stuffs her booty into a little burglar's bag.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOAKES
dialogues.text: Breakfast is eight sharp. Boiled eggs with toast soldiers today. None for the tardy. The door slams leaving Cavendish blinking for a moment-- Then at once he is up and hurrying into his clothes.  98.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “You can maintain power over people as long as you give them something. Rob a man of everything and that man will no longer be in your power.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She identifies the quote.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Alexander Solzhenitsyn. He consults the orison.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: 20th century philosopher. Complete works banned by Unanimity Executive Order 2131. How do you know about him?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: A book.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: An actual book? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: It was a gift. INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Sonmi is alone, soaking in the dull glow of her monitor, eyes gulping down information. At the sound of the key in the door, she quickly shuts of the machine and crosses the room, grabbing a beer from th fridge just as the door opens revealing-- Chang.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Hello Sonmi. He smiles slightly, taking the beer from her. She closes door, hiding the flush of heat she feels in her cheeks whenever he says her name.  99.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Seer Chang.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: I told you I am not a Seer. Call me Hae-Joo.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Hae-Joo.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Mr. Kim departed for Sextet Eve holiday early this morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Three days all to yourself. Any big plans? The question confuses her.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I still have four hundred and thirty years of Western literature...

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Not exactly what I had in mind. It’s Sextet Eve. Don’t you deserve a holiday too? The words don’t compute. CHANG (CONT’D) Come on. I’ve got a surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish storms from his room into the hallway, pausing get his bearings. He shoots down the hall toward reception, slippers clappi determinedly against the polished industrial linoleum. An uneasiness begins to fill Cavendish as baroque music l in the identical chair-lined corridors.  Suddenly a leprous GNOME still in his pajamas grips the wrist and lifts a jar of hazelnut butter.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME
dialogues.text: If you want to get a signal, you’1ll need one of these. Cavendish grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: You've mistaken me for someone else. 100. him by He pries the man’s hand from his wrist and continues down hall. He has become unnerved, however. Something about Au House isn’t right. He slows as he passes a window and sees the dining room. Dawning seeps into Cavendish as he sees the diners at Aur House are all in their seventies and up. He doubles his pace, features reddening as he passes a hulking ORDERLY. MRS. JUDD greets him with an Oil of Olay smile at Recepti

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Cavendish. Feeling super this morning?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Yes. No. An absurd misunderstanding has occurred.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I ah-- I checked in last night believing Aurora House was a hotel. My brother made the booking, you see. His idea of a practical joke. But listen. You have a bigger problem closer to home - some demented bitch called Noakes is running about the place impersonating a chambermaid. Probably riddled with Alzheimer's. She stole my keys! Now, in a go-go bar in Phuket, that'd be par for the course, but in an old wrecks' home in Hull? You'd get closed down if I was an inspector, you know.  101. Mrs. Judd's smile is battery acid. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) Right. I’1l need my keys back, straight away. He raps his knuckles on the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Aurora House is your home now, Mr. Cavendish. Your signature authorizes us to apply compliancy. And I'd get out of the habit of referring to my sister in those tones.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Compliancy? Signature? Sister?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: The custody document you signed last night. Your residency papers.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) No, no, no-- That was the hotel registry! Never mind, it's all academic. My, this will make a heck of a dinner-party story. Once I've strangled my brother. Bill him, by the way. Only I must insist on having my keys returned, And you'd better call me a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Most of our guests get cold feet on their first mornings.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: My feet are quite warm, but I haven't made myself clear. If you don 't-

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Mr. Cavendish, why don't you eat your breakfast first and-

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Keys! A group of residents have stopped to watch the escalating exchange.  102.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: We have your written permission to hold your valuables in the office safe.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Then I must speak with the management.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: That would be my sister, Nurse Noakes.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Noakes? Management?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Nurse Noakes.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Then I must speak with the board of governors, or the owner.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: They would be me.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Your telephone, please. I wish to inform the police--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: Residents aren’t permitted to-- He slams his hand on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I am not a ruddy resident!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JUDD
dialogues.text: You’1l find that temper tantrums won’t help you at Aurora House.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Look, you’re breaking the ruddy-- Anti-Incarceration Act or something and I bloody hell won’t stand for this! Before she can stop him, Cavendish wheels with a grandios gesture and slams out the double-door exit. The cold snaps at his skin as he marches down the curving driveway, breath puffing from his nostrils like a locomot  103. He rounds a bend and sees a shaggy GIANT in overalls risi from an overturned lawn-mower. He claps the dust from his gloves.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSMAN
dialogues.text: off somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: You bet I am! To the land of the living. He strides decisively past hiding his growing confusion i the layout of the grounds. He follows the drive and realizes he has found himself ba at the dining room annex. Cavnedish huffs as the Undead of Aurora House watch him through the wall of glass. He raises his hands in mocking horror. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) Soylent Green is people! Soylent Green is made of people! They stare at him puzzled, when one of them taps on the window and pointing behind him. Cavendish turns and sees the groundsman coming at him fas

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSMAN
dialogues.text: Oy! Get back here you!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: You keep away from me or I’1l be forced to name you an accomplice in the police report. The groundsman grabs for his shoulder but Cavendish swats away and angles himself behind a cart of clay pots.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSMAN
dialogues.text: I've better things to do than this...

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Then go and do them, you bloody sodding soap-dodger! Cavendish heaves at the cart toppling it the ceramic pots crashing down shattering at the giant’s feet.  104.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSMAN
dialogues.text: Right! Cavendish’s eyes go wide as the Groundsman springs at him this time knocking away his flailing defenses, arms wrapp him up in a crushing bear-hug. The stink of fertilizer fills Cavendish’s nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Get your hands off of me, you cruddy ruddy rugger bugger yob! The bear-hug tightens and Cavendish, with a breathless, silent scream, is abandoned by all force to fight back. Like a moldy sack of flour, the groundsman carries Cavend by the picture window of Aurora House gapers.

dialogues.text: Where did Chang take you?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: The rest of it.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Outside, fat snowflakes are falling on slate roofs and granite walls. Like Solzhenitsyn laboring in Vermont, I shall beaver away in exile, far from the city that knit- ted my bones. The music swells as Chang looks over at Sonmi whose eyes quiver with tears. We aren’t sure if she is happy or sad.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unlike Solzhenitsyn, I shan't be alone. We do not see whom he is referring to, staying focused on Sonmi and Chang. INT. FROBISHER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 Frobisher eases back onto his bed.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve taken Jocasta as a lover. Jocasta casually opens her robe, revealing her mature but well cared for body. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Don't alarm yourself, Sixsmith! Only in the carnal sense. Don't wish to brag, but her first visit at night didn't take me by surprise. They begin making love; Frobisher attending with a connoisseur's care.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Really, you should try women. They enchant in different ways: a section of strings rather than horns, delicate, subtle, their desire like a secret and yet invariably, when one unlocks a woman's body, her box of confidences also spills. What secrets, I wonder, will tumble from Madame Crommelynck’s lips? He kisses parts of her body that no one has kissed for a time and she moans with pleasure.  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Industrial skylights cast perfect slabs of blue moonlight along the floor of the otherwise dark corridor. They shim like sacrificial altars in the quiet of Aurora House.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The stage is set. Cavendish creeps down the hall in a series of stealthy serpentine stop-starts.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Aurora House, the chess board. He edges into a shadow opposite of a security camera.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They will learn this certainty of certainties, a battle of wits with a Cavendish is surely a losing proposition. One final quick dash and he enters Nurse Judd’s office. INT. NURSE JUDD’S OFFICE - NIGHT Cavendish lifts the phone, fingers dancing over the keypa The receiver chirps in his ear as it rings.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Come on, Denny old boy... After an almost interminable wait, the line is answered.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who in the bloody hell is this? Do you have any idea what time it is? Cavendish’s face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Denny? It’s me, Denny! Tim!

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Timothy? What? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I think you bloody well know where I am!  107.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, I was assured there wasn’t a public phone at Aurora House...

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Of course there isn’t, I’ve pinched this one.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I will have to have a word with the Governess about this. A man in your condition shouldn’t be allowed to wander at all hours.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Alright, Den. You’ve had your fun. I think it’s high time to put an end to this little game of yours.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look Tim, it’s been nice catching up with you, but it’s late--

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? This is your brother! Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think a better question in this instance would be, what have you done to deserve this?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I-- I don’t know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come now, Timothy. Don’t insult me. You can’t think that I didn’t know about you and Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Georgette? Cavendish swallows.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago, Denholme.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m afraid your penance and reconciliation have come. Time to account for your crimes.  108.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Look Den, I never meant to hurt you- Cavendish flusters. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) I’m-- I’m so sorry. Denholme chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: DENHOLME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No apologies necessary Timbo. Your exile to Aurora House is more than enough reparation. Nice and tidy. Not to mention humane. You see, as it stands now, I won’t have to kill you. The line clicks dead as the lights pop on. An extremely agitated Nurse Judd stands in the doorway, flanked by Mr. Withers. INT. FROBISHER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 Frobisher is smoking a cigarette. Jocasta beside him, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: You are so much like Vyvyan... The comparison flatters him.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The way the light catches your eye, the silhouette of your shoulder and neck; all these little things that remind me of him when we first met. He turns towards her.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Where were you when you met? She is shy about it even though it is a fond memory.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: I was a student, like you-- Suddenly, someone pounds hurriedly on the door.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Frobisher! Open up!  109. The doorknob is rattled.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hurry, man! Open the door! Panicking, Jocasta buries herself beneath the covers as Frobisher wraps a robe around himself and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Ayrs, what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Who cares? I don’t know! I’ve heard a melody, boy. For violin. Quick. Paper. Find a pen! Frobisher looks helplessly around as Ayrs rushes past him

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why the deuce do you lock your door if you sleep with the windows open? He falls into the chair near the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard it in a dream... I was ina nightmarish cafe, blaring, bright light but underground, with no way out and the waitresses... they all +--+. had the same face. Frobisher finds pen and paper, then adjusts the second ch so Ayrs won’t look towards the bed. AYRS (CONT’D) There was music playing, compressed, hollow sounding but unlike any music I have ever heard in my life. He closes his eyes and tries to conjure it. AYRS (CONT’D) It began as Wagner’s Tristan Chord, hovering on the edge of dissonance... augmented fourth, augmented sixth... Frobisher scribbles the notes.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Augmented second above what root? Cc?  110.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Ge B?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: -. yes.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Flat?

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Wait, no, I don’t know, help me, Robert! Help me, it’s sipping away! AYRS grabs hold of Frobisher’s arm but the younger man doesn’t know how to help him.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was so clear a minute ago... He closes his eyes and listens for it again. He sags, defeated. AYRS (CONT’D) I’ve lost it... it’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: It’ll come to you sir. The minute you stop trying to find it, it’ll find you.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: You are naive, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I am anything but.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: There is a gulf between these chairs.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: You are older, true--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Fifty years is more than time--  lll.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: But what you want is no different from what I want. A beat. FROBISHER (CONT’D) The gulf is an illusion. Ayrs throws a quizzical smile at Frobisher.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Robert? You’re young, talented, intelligent and by all accounts not wholly repugnant. Why do you stay? Frobisher sits in his chair knowing that he cannot answer question honestly.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I have learned more from you in six months then two years with the parrots of Caius. Ayrs smiles but knows it is not the whole truth. He hauls himself to his feet and they say good night to each other FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) How I longed to speak the truth, to look him straight in the eye and say, “because of you, sir. Because of the way you look at me when my fingers coax your “tar-tatty-tatty- tar” into a gentle melody. Because of the way you conduct with your cigarette. Because of the way your soul swims in your eyes. Because you are my Verlaine and I, your reckless, desperate Rimbaud. Because this is the relationship I have been waiting for all my life.” The door closes with a heaviness and Frobisher sags again it until-- Jocasta climbs out from the bed, her expression a bemused smile gleaned by insight.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: I think my husband has fallen in love with you.  112. Her words send an electric thrill through his body but he hides it behind his own shy smile.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Come now, don’t make me feel the cad. Her stare bores to his soul.

dialogues.speaker: JOCASTA
dialogues.text: We both know what you are. INT. CAMBRIDGE COLLEGE - SIXSMITH’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1 Sixsmith sits in the dark room, reading by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I think my husband has fallen in love with you.” How many times did I replay her words in my mind. Don’t be angry with me for telling you the truth, Sixsmith. I had to tell someone. Try to understand. Music has come into my life. We hear the Cloud Atlas Sextet begin to swell. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Music as beautiful as any I have ever heard. Alone, Sixsmith begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MOLYNEUX
dialogues.text: Mr. Boerhaave, my bottle is empty.

dialogues.speaker: BOERHAAVE
dialogues.text: Aye, aye, sir. Boerhaave smiles as his finger tightens-- INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Boom-sook fires. The arrow hits Sonmi and she screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewing can’t just stand and watch.  119.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Captain, hear me out-- He moves and “stumbles” into Boerhaave who fires, missing wildly. Autua pays no attention to what is happening, scampering one end to the other-- Boerhaave spits venom, grabbing hold of Ewing.

dialogues.speaker: BOERHAAVE
dialogues.text: Damn you, Quillcock! Abettors share the same fate as stowaways on this ship!

dialogues.speaker: OLD SALTY DOG
dialogues.text: Cap’n look! He’s got fish-hooks for toes. The entire crew is transfixed as Autua swings out using h entire body as a counter-weight-- The great sail billowing out like a parachute behind him- Landing gently on the deck as the salty sea dog cackles w laughter. OLD SALTY DOG (CONT’D) Haa! The darkies salt as I am! The captain rubs his chin.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MOLYNEUX
dialogues.text: Mr. Boerhaave, it appears we have an addition to our crew. Be sure he earns his keep. He takes the rifle and leaves Boerhaave glaring at Ewing. INT. BOOM-SOOK’S DORMROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Sonmi is on the floor, her ear badly bleeding --- --- when the door explodes off its hinges. Enforcers pour into the room. Boom-Sook shrieks and falls the floor, cowering as he and his friends are bagged and cuffed. Sonmi has only a moment before she too is bagged and arrested.  120. INT. SWANNEKKE POWER PLANT - SIXSMITH’S OFFICE - DAY - YE 1974 The door opens as a scientist catches Luisa in the act of looking through Sixsmith’s files. His name is ISAAC SACHS Their eyes lock and Isaac feels something he would never expected: familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: What are you doing in here? There’s no good answer to that question. ISAAC (CONT’D) You better come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay Li is looking everywhere for Luisa.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Here she is, Ms. Li. Found her by the chem labs... looking for a bathroom. Luisa realizes that Isaac has just covered for her.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Sorry... it’s that time again.

dialogues.speaker: FAY LI
dialogues.text: Say no more. Issac, do you mind if I conscript you a little longer to walk Ms. Rey through the facility?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Lucky me.

dialogues.speaker: FAY LI
dialogues.text: Think of her as an anthropologist, here to study our tribe. Don’t bore her with math. (to Luisa) Watch out for him. He’s got a reputation. One of Swannekke’s “most eligible.” She flutters away, a cloud of “Charlie” in her wake. The silence between them is immediately uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: ++-why did you do that? Isaac searches for an answer.  121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi sits frightened in the corner of the cell. After a long beat, the cell door grinds open. Several faceless Enforcers enter and flank the room. BOARDMAN MEPHI enters with the air of unassailable author Sonmi stands.

dialogues.speaker: BOARDMAN MEPHI
dialogues.text: You have caused quite a sensation. He steps close, examining her. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Everyone wants to know, can you tell? Is it somehow visible? I tell these buffoons, consciousness is not a rash. That’s what makes it so dangerous. That even beneath this generic, manufactured features there can be thoughts that terrify the whole of Unnaminity. Hmmmm, yes? Sonmi doesn’t know how to answer. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Shall I explain? The research facility at our University generates roughly two million library download requests per semester. The vast majority are course texts and related articles; the remainder relate to anything from real estate to stock prices. The point is, Sonmi, it takes a reader of truly eclectic habits for my friends the librarians to bother alerting me. He reads from his handsony.  BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Argueto’s One Day of Life, Funes’s Rememberences, Orwell’s 1984, Solzhenitsyn’s Gulag Archipelago, Murakami’s Underground, Gibbon’s Decline and Fall and if that were not enough for rendition, a brazen- as-you-please request for all references to that cancer in our corpocratic body- Union! He shakes his head. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Two days of detective work by my able-bodied assistant and it became obvious that your master Boom-sook reading Wittgenstein defied all credulity. Conclusively, our dissident-manque was apparently the first Ascended fabricant, sister- server to the notorious Yoona-939. He smiles like someone who doesn’t smile very often. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Now what? The Corprocrats want you euthanized as a deviant. The Manufacturer is demanding a period of study to determine if they are responsible for a recall or if you are an anomaly. The pyschogenomicists are screaming for an immediate cerebral vivisection. Sonmi can feel the walls closing in around her. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) In the end, a compromise has been reached. You shall be put through a battery of cross-disciplinary tests for a period that shall not exceed a full month, after which your brain will be delivered for complete diagnostic while the rest of your body is incinerated. Mephi turns heading for the door, before pausing. BOARDMAN MEPHI (CONT’D) Seems almost a shame... but the Will of the People must be protected. 122.  123. The Enforcers file out behind him, the door sealing itsel tight, leaving Sonmi completely alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish lays in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Trapped in a world where a clock has no hands. Primo Levi’s “The Drowned and the Saved” scrolled in epitaphs across my thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pale nurse serves Cavendish his lunch; a tepid lamb cho starch grenade potatoes and canned carrots.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Freedom” the fatuous jingle of our civilization but only those deprived of it have the barest inkling of what it really is. Cavendish sits in front of his tray staring at the horror holds. A nearby couple watches him intently as he surreptitiousl pockets his meds. This is ERNIE and VERONICA. INT. CAVENDISH’S ROOM, AURORA HOUSE - DAY Cavendish stands at the window, the afternoon sun throwin crosshatch of shadow on his face from the security cage.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Behold your future, Cavendish the Younger. You will not apply for membership, but the tribe of the elderly will claim you. Behind him a once stately woman and her colleague a ricke greyhound of a man in a blazer stare in consternation.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Look here, boyo, we know you’ve had a rough time of it, but we're here to help.  124.

dialogues.speaker: GWENDOLIN
dialogues.text: A position to record Residents Committee meeting minutes has opened. A fine opportunity for you to jolly well get involved! I understand you were in publishing. Cavendish turns, his chin jutting coldly.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I still am in publishing. Do I look like I should be here? Dust motes hang in the silence.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Psst. Your fly’s undone, boyo. He turns back to the window.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Get out. The two exit leaving him once again alone. CAVENDISH (V.O.) (CONT’D) This inescapable reality will become evident only when the last vestiges of your dignity are stripped away. Cavendish zips his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi is strapped into a testing device. Various screens pulse with MRI-like images, others reading chemistry fluctuations and organ functions.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You accepted that your life had come to an end? A measure of electricity is sent through a synapse in her brain. Her body convulses against her restraints.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wished to be as strong as the German thinker Nietzsche. I wished to not merely bear what was necessary, but to love it. The course ends and her body sags.  The scientists nod and make notes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In truth, every day all I really wished for was an end to my suffering, for someone to release me. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - NIGHT A pale and sickly Ewing collapses upon his bed.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Henry, I feel terrible... so weak. Everything hurts.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: The days events, the excitements, it was all too much. Tomorrow you must rest. 125.
