Goose smiles, his over large teeth yellow in the swaying lantern light, as he prepares another spoonful of medicin GOOSE (CONT’D) Soon, Adam. It’1ll all be over soon. Adam inhales the medicine through his nose, Goose still holding the spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catkin slurps from the spoon as Zachry feeds her.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Scorp’n fish soup! Mmmhmm! My fav’rite. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma says you guidin’ Meronym up Mauna Kea. (slurp) Call’d you a bravey-balled bullock.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Me’n’Meronym got a pact. You know, a pact’s’a’pact.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: Then pact with me. Promise, you’1ll come back, safewise, both’a you.  126. He smiles and weaves his fingers into hers.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Yay... I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac is supposed to be giving Luisa a tour of the containment chamber. Instead they stand at a railing overlooking the massive structure.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: The funny thing is I’m not even supposed to be here. I was meant to be in Washington but this stupid air-traffic controller strike screwed everything up so I have to take the red-eye tonight. Do you ever feel like the universe is against you? She takes a joint out of her cigarette pack.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: All the time. You mind? Trying to be cool.

dialogues.speaker: ISSAC
dialogues.text: No, no. Go ahead. She lights it, taking a strong hit, while he looks around making sure the coast is clear.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: You seem nervous, Issac. Do I make you nervous? She offers him the joint. He hedges, than takes it.

dialogues.speaker: ISSAC
dialogues.text: No, uh-uh, actually the opposite. She cocks an eyebrow while he takes a hit and coughs a little. He passes the joint back to her.  127. ISSAC (CONT’D) I had a girlfriend once, I mean, I’ve had lots of girlfriends, well not lots, I’ve had my fair share, but there was one who you kind of remind me of. She hated math and kept trying to get me to read Carlos Castenada. You ever read any of that stuff? She smiles, nodding, blowing smoke out into the great concrete void.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ISSAC
dialogues.text: I don’t really believe any of that past life nonsense but every once in a while... I don’t know, I can’t explain it but I knew when I opened that door, somehow I knew you were going to be there. Isaac takes another hit, enjoying the taste of her lipsti

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: But that doesn’t explain why you covered for me.

dialogues.speaker: ISSAC
dialogues.text: Rufus Sixsmith was a mentor to me. Taught me how to play chess, how to make a good pot of tea, the best way to enjoy cricket (asleep on the couch) and when the aforementioned girlfriend dumped me for a guy who she believed had been her concubine in a past life, he gave me a shoulder to cry on. He was a good friend.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Two operators partially dressed in radiation suits, enter bridge and pass by. He hides the joint and does his best “tour guide.”

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: --It is the safest and most sophisticated containment system in the world.  128. The operators exit the other side. He watches the smoke rise in wisps and disappear into the concrete void.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They destroyed most of the copies of the report.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Most? He looks at her like someone about to jump off a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: There is no good choice here, is there? If I help you, I could lose my job or... worse. But if I don’t, a lot of people... it’1l be worse than worse. After a moment of silence, she looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: You have to do, whatever you can’t not do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi looks up as the enforcers open the cell. The experiments have taken their toll. Her perfect features a worn and haggard. She seems near to death.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Please. I can’t... One of the Enforcers steps forward. Her own face is reflected in the mirrored visor of his helmet. He pulls a flask from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Drink this. There is something familiar in his voice. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1846 Autua holds Ewing, tipping a cup of water to his lips.  129.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: You gotta drink, Missa Ewing. And eat. You need food. He reaches into his pocket pulling out the same kind of r Ewing brought him. AUTUA (CONT’D) Look. Like you brought me. He smiles. Ewing tries to return the smile. Tries to eat but it’s not working. AUTUA (CONT’D) Come on, Missa Ewing. I ain’t gonn’a let you die here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish lies listlessly in his bed, trying to finish reading the Luis Rey manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My only salvation came in the form of the manuscript I had brought with me. I read it like a bible. The struggles of Luisa Rey became my own. A letter suddenly slides under the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa opens the hood of Garcia. She stares at something t someone put in her car; it glows pale white against the darkness-— The Sixsmith Report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac Sachs sits on the plane, writing in his journal.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Exposition: The problem of the “actual past” and the “virtual past” can be illustrated by a historical event like the sinking of the Titanic.  130. The camera booms down to find a black attache case beneat empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym and Zachry reach a plateau where there was once a large city. The shells that were once buildings, slump and lay like s of armor of a medieval battle, long after the carrion had hollowed them out. Trees grow out through windows, vines drip from moss cove satellite dishes, vehicles, partially buried seem more li grown-over crypts than cars.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The disaster as it actually occurred fades into obscurity as witnesses die off, documents are destroyed and the wreck itself dissolves in its Atlantic grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher plays the Atlas, half dressed, lost in a fugue, scribbling notes quickly as the music pours out of him.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yet a virtual sinking, created out of reworked memory, hearsay, fiction, in short- belief grows ever more “true”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa slams her hood. Jumps in the car and peels out. As the car passes we see the lens of a security camera watching her.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The virtual past is malleable, easily pressed into the service of the present as Powers vie for legitimacy and the right to control the actual and the virtual future.  131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish opens the letter. Inside is a note that reads: “You want out? Find the Boiler room. After lunch.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi acquiesces, nodding, ready to continue. The Enforce that gave her the drink, lifts her and they escort her ou her cell.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The uncreated and the dead exist in both the actual and virtual past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the music stops. Frobisher’s fingers are as still as a nervous deer. Ayrs, in his bed clothes, looking as if just woken from a dream sits in his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: That’s it. The music from my dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa races towards the crest of the bridge. Behind her, blue sedan with its lights turned off glides in pursuit w the same menace as a shark. We have seen this scene before.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Symmetry demands that future creations and future selves wait to be influenced by our present self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane speeds for its take off. Isaac continues to wri

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Proposition: I have fallen in love with Luisa Rey. Is this possible? I just met her and yet I feel like-- Beneath him the attache explodes.  132. Having just lifted off, the plane is ripped open by a fireball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue car accelerates and pulls up beside her. Luisa looks over and sees a face that frightens her-- Bill Smoke. He slams his car into Luisa’s. She screams, fighting to k control as-- His larger car smashes her into the guard-rail which hold once but then shatters-- Sending the Volkswagen lurching off the bridge out into t open air. Luisa screams as the black water, shimmering like snakesk in the moonlight rushes up at her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The volkswagon impacts; an explosion of furious underwate bubbles scattering out. Inside, Luisa smashes her head against the steering wheel blood gushing from the gash as-- She is knocked unconscious. From above, the car sinks in lazy liquid speed; the hood coughs open and the Sixsmith report dreamily floats out a into the abyss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayrs looks like he has seen a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: How do you know that music? Where did it come from?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: It is the piece I have been working on. I call it The Cloud Atlas Sextet. Ayrs wheels himself closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, Robert. This is from my dream. That night I came to your room, this is the music I heard in my head. Somehow I gave it to you. Frobisher smiles and begins to play gently.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: While the idea of a sub-conscious connection to you excites my imagination, I’m afraid there is a more rational explanation. 133. The music casts a romantic spell over the conversation. FROBISHER (CONT’D) I have been working on the Atlas for weeks now and I suspect you heard it and incorporated it into your dream. The old man wheels towards the piano, staring prospector might stare at a pan full of gold.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: This, Robert... is meant for Eternal Recurrence. Let me have it, and I will explore its hidden secrets. Bring them to the surface.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: The Atlas, I believe, is the only thing I have ever done in my life that has value. Yet, I would give it to you, give it gladly, if only this... situation was different.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Different how? He is unable to look at Ayrs, playing softly.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: There are whole movements in the Atlas that I wrote imagining us meeting again and again in different lives, in different ages...

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. It is the essence of Eternal Recurrence. We are bathing in the same creative water, Robert. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at it asa  134.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something as important as this cannot be described as yours or mine. It is ours. He stops playing. His heart stands on the threshold of it closet. He shifts on the bench turning towards the older

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: That is exactly how I feel, Vyvyan. That and more. He puts his hand on Ayr’s leg. Ayrs stares down at the hand on his knee. It is impossibl read the old man’s reaction. FROBISHER (CONT’D) You can have the Atlas, Vyvyan. You can have every musical thought I ever have. All I need is one thing in return.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: You. It is impossible to read the old man’s reaction.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t belong here. We both know it’s true. Come away with me. Leave Zeldelghem. Leave this rotting prison that reeks of mushrooms and mold. Leave your wife. Let us flee and be free to live however many days we have left, together. Run away with me, Vyvyan. Run away with me... Trembling, Frobisher dares to lift his other hand and tou Ayrs’ cheek with his fingertips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi is led through the halls by the Enforcers that surr and dwarf her. They march for a moment when one of the Enforcers moves w casual ease, as if he were pulling a pack of cigarettes f his pocket--  135. Takes out a gun and spins towards her, aiming at what loo like her head-- But turns out to be the Enforcer behind her. His head explodes inside his helmet. Before anyone can react, he spins back and puts two more dum bullets in the remaining Enforcer. Sonmi is paralyzed. He pulls off his helmet revealing himself. It is Chang. Without thinking about it, she throws her arms around him clinging as a child might cling to a returned parent.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Tears squeeze from her closed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: ...they hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: I know. I know. I’m going to get you out of here. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi follows Chang as they rush through a labyrinth of halls. He leads her towards a door.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: In here. Alarms begin to sound. CHANG (CONT’D) Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a large loading dock where supplies for the pr arrive. Three ENFORCERS react, training their guns on him.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: It’s all right, it’s all right.  136. He waves his fake ID at them. They are confused while the alarm continues to blare.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m working for Boardman Mephi-- He lifts his gun and kills them all before they have a ch to blink.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In here. He puts Sonmi inside a transport filled with bags of laun He strips off his Enforcer uniform. Underneath he is wear a bright colored Laundry Engineer uniform.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay hidden. He climbs into the driver seat. More Enforcers are arrivi at the dock as he eases the transport out the bay door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi is jostled as the car begins to pick up speed.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Chang!

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: I told you: Hae-Joo. Chang watches the screens for pursuing vehicles. CHANG (CONT’D) Uh oh. In the distance, several individual pod-cars shoot into t their tube, while above the prison a large hovercraft ris up. Like a cross between a harrier jet and a blackhawk helicopter, it looks fast and mean. CHANG (CONT’D) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Trouble.  137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayrs stares at Frobisher whose trembling hand is about to slowly caress his face. The silence stretches until-- Ayrs begins to laugh. It is a sound that has broken more hearts than any other. Frobisher’s hands jolt backwards as if hit by high voltag

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Vyvyan Ayrs abroad with his shameless sodomite! He roars, the cacophony of laughter exploding like violen cymbals.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry-- I thought--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: You thought? You thought what?! That I might fancy a little buggering from a fine young dandy like yourself? The laughter dies, smothered by disgust. AYRS (CONT’D) I’m not sure whether the idea strikes me as more ridiculous or repugnant. Frobisher hardens.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I’1l pack my bags and be gone by morning. He stands and heads for the door but the force of Ayrs vo stops him.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: You will do no such thing! You will leave only when I say you can leave. Frobisher turns.  Frobisher 138.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until then you will continue working on Eternal Recurrence. When it is finished then I will decide what to do with you. sets his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: You can’t keep me here. I’m leaving. Good luck with Eternal Recurrence. I’m sure a sterile old fuck like yourself is still capable of something completely immemorable. Again he heads for the door and again Ayrs stops him. Frobisher Frobisher

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: I suggest you think about this, Robert. Really think. Leave and you will only compound your mistake. Think about reputation. Reputation is everything in our society. Mine is beyond reproach. Yours, my disinherited, gambling, bankrupt reprobate, is expired. realizes Ayrs knows more than he thought he did. AYRS (CONT’D) Did you not think we would check up on someone living under our roof? Mackerras’ himself wrote and I quote, “He is a prostitute whose liaisons with perverts and sodomites were commonplace in his brief and forgettable career at Caius. Lock up the silverware.” Unquote. feels the world crumbling in on him. AYRS (CONT’D) Be warned, leave Zedelghem without my consent and all musical society will know of the scoundrel, Robert Frobisher and the unspeakable crimes he forced upon a helpless old man. A smile twists across Ayrs mouth that reminds us of Old Georgie.  139.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After that, even if you compose one of the greatest symphonies ever written, no one will ever hear it because no one will want anything to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish sits alone at a table, unable to bring himself eat the gray food. He pulls the note from his pocket, its words taunting him “You want out? Find the boiler room. After lunch.” He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stalks around the kitchen, searching until he sees a stairway leading down. Nurse Noakes passes by and he quic ducks out of sight. When the coast is clear, he slips down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He descends into the dark basement. Pipes and wires canop the ceiling like jungle vines. A lone light bulb guides him deeper into the netherworld. At the end of the hall he sees a heavy metal door. Beyond there is a glow of warm light and the sound of voices. He hesitates, uncertain if this is a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You all right, Zachry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym and Zachry near the edges of the large city, risi up the side of the mountain. Improvised mass graves surround them. The wind mourns. It is a haunted place.  140.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Valleysman stay clear’o here. Place o’tears and sick’birth an’ mukelung. Angry ances’try buri’d here. Can’t you hear’m wailin’?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: It’s jus’a wind. In the darkness of a bombed building, in a hole like a ru screaming mouth, Zachry sees Old Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Say’s you. The devil smiles and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish steals himself and pushes open the door. Three faces gathered around a makeshift table, look up. I is ERNIE, VERONICA and MR. MEEKS. Veronica smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: I told you he’d come. Cavendish isn’t sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can I ask a ques’un?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flames of the campfire lick at Zachry who sits with o eye on the darkness beyond.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Yay.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: You really ain’t feary o ‘meetin’ Old Georgie when we get to the summit, like Truman Napes?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I more scaresome ‘bout the weather then Old Georgie.  141.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: You don’t b’lief he’s real?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: He ain’t real for me, but that don’t mean he can’t be real for you.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: But who tripped the Fall, if it weren’t Old Georgie? She looks at him, knowing this is moving towards dangerou ground.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: The True-true? He nods. MERONYM (CONT’D) The Old Uns. It doesn’t make any sense.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What? That’s jus’a’rope o’smoke. The Old Uns got the Smart. They mastered sick and seeds, they make mir’cles and fly ‘cross the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: True. All true. But they got somethin’ else. A hunger’n their hearts‘n that hunger was stronger’n all their Smart.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Hunger for what?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: A hunger for more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young Sixsmith crosses the campus tearing open the late letter from Frobisher.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Divorces. Very messy affairs. I told Ayrs I would sleep on his proposal. Of course, I lied.  142. INT. CAMBRIDGE COLLEGE - SIXSMITH’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 193 Sixsmith starts to pack, throwing only bare essentials in bag.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two things became clear. Hanging myself from Zedelghem’s flagpole was preferable to letting that parasite plunder my talents a day longer and I must complete my Sextet. I can’t do it here, so tonight I plan to make my escape. Sixsmith slams open the door, racing from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter is still in Sixsmith’s hand as he stares out t window thinking about how he should have done this a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “It will end in tears.” You warned me. I suppose I’m as hopeless as Adam Ewing, oblivious to all the unspeakable forms lying in wait for us round history’s corner. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1846 Close on Ewing’s swollen hand; his ring finger is a disturbing shade of blue as Goose clamps his metal pliers into place.

dialogues.speaker: EWING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My condition worsens with the change of weather. My fingers are so swollen that Henry is forced to cut my wedding ring lest it prevent circulation and the onset of dropsy. The idea of losing this symbol distresses me beyond measure.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Don’t be a silly puffin, Adam. I’m sure your wife would set your health and the survival of your finger above a metal loop. Clack. The heavy pliers bite through the wedding band.  143. Goose slides off the ring and inspects it. GOOSE (CONT’D) Besides, I know an excellent Spanish goldsmith who works with such alacrity that your Tilda may not have to know it was ever removed. He smiles in the swaying lamp-light while slipping the ri into his vest pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie fills four glasses with Irish malt. Ernie, VERONICA MR. MEEKS sit with Cavendish in the secret clubhouse.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: First problem we got is the problem of trust.

dialogues.speaker: MR MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: We could use code names but truth is, I’d probably be the first to forget mine. So, Mr. Cavendish, this is Veronica Costello and Mr. Meeks.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: MR MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know. They raise their glasses in toast.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: To trust. They drink. Cavendish is nearly overcome with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ahhh... like rain on the Serengeti. How’d you get it?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: I’ve got a few tricks left up the sleeve as Noakes-sey and her knuckle-draggers will soon discover. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But be warned, most jail-breaks are stillborn, snuffed before they even get started-- Loose lips sink ships.

dialogues.speaker: MR MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What about the parrot, then? If ever there was a likely songbird.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Mr. Meeks is a fine and honorable gentleman. He would never betray us. She kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: MR MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Besides no one’s ever heard him say anything else.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Then why do you need me? Why isn’t he your third man?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: We’re not sure he wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: More to the point, any jailbreak’s a risky proposition. One little cock up and we’re dangling at her Majesty’s pleasure. S’truth, we’re not sure ol’ Meeksey’s up to snuff. Question is, old man, are you? Cavendish knows the answer to that question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enforcer helicopter roars after the delivery transpor It glides up to the side of the tube, maneuvering with ha like grace so that the Enforcers are looking at Chang.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Unanimity requires your compliance. Stop your vehicle and prepare to be boarded.  145. The voice is heard both outside and inside Chang’s transp Chang begins gesturing wildly.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Mok-tang non sungh! Bim-bop!

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Sungh nar-bar, bar-sungh! Bim-bop, nack-bop!

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ migrant monkey-talk.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Why do they hire these greasy fuck- wits?

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: This is your first and only warning. Stop now or we will open fire.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Like anyone would give a shit if we smoked an illegal.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Ja-yah! Ja-yah! Chang hits the decel and the transport slows while the bu like Enforcer cars race towards them. Chang moves into the cargo section. In a plastic crate he finds several weapons and supplies. He grabs a roll of medical tape.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Hae-Joo... She has risen partially from her hiding spot and watches as he tears a piece of tape. SONMI-451 (CONT’D) I can’t go back to that place. He nods gravely.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: It won’t happen. You have my word.  146. He reloads the charge in his gun. INT. AYR’S CHATEAU - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 The door of Ayrs’ bedroom creeps open; a knife blade of l cutting into the darkness. A shadow steals across the room. Ayrs sleeps peacefully while Frobisher stealthily slides the drawer of his nightstand. Inside the gun gleams, nestled in a chamois cloth, beside saucer of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The room stank of bitter medicine. Had to fight off an unaccountably strong urge to open Ayrs’ throat with my pen knife. Not quite deja vu, More jamais vu. He takes the saucer of bullets which rattle as he slips t into his pocket. AYRS stirs but does not wake. Then, he takes the gun.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Curiously heavy things, guns. Why did I take it exactly? Can’t say. An intuition. A sense of significance. That from this point on, there was no going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry and Meronym have stopped along an old ruined road into the mountainside. Their path ends where a bridge has crumbled away into a rocky chasm. Meronym takes out a strange gun from her bag and looks up a light snow has begun to fall, zig-zagging in the gustin wind.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: From the look of those clouds, we don’t have a lot of time. She aims the gun and fires a grappling hook up and across chasm. It catches on a knot of rusting re-bar.  147.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHARY
dialogues.text: Whaaaah! She hands him the rope.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: You first. He looks up and knows what’s waiting for him. Zachry scales the rope a fierce wind biting into him with sting of shards of glass. He slips and zippers open the s in his palms. When he reaches the crest, his stomach drops at the site their destination; an array of monolithic towers looming ominously against a roiling black sky. The threatening blizzard swirls like a snow globe. Below he sees Meronym’s climb is going harder. Zachry beg hand over hand pulling her up to help. His hands burn with the effort. When she is almost to the top, the strain forcing beads o sweat on his brow, Zachry looks up, time slowing to a hal Sparkling snowflakes freeze in the air if they were a sna shot.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Zachry the cowardy, you trodd’n on the Devil’s ground now, Vall’ysman. Zachry turns and along the ridge he sees Old Georgie swis snowflakes out of his way as he closes in on him. His eyes gleam unnaturally as he cranes his spindly body forward and hisses. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) I’m sayin’ this jus’ once. The offlander ain’t gettin’ to the top. You let-go that rope. Zachry looks down at the frozen Meronym dangling twenty f above the rocky ground.  148. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Her fall may not kill her when I let time flow again, but them rocks b'low'll bust her spine'n'legs an' she'll not s’rive the night. I’1l let her consider her’follyin's.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Why not jus’ kill her yerself, then? Old Georgie bellows.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Why-why-why? I want you to do it, an' here's why-why-why. See, if you don't let-~go that rope, she’1ll be leadin’ you straight into a place there ain’t no return, I promise. Ain’t nothing in there for a soul to do but rot, forev’r’n then some. Jus’ ask ol’ Truman Napes when ya’ see/m. A chill hits Zachry. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) So you ever wanna see Catkin again, you best let-go that rope.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: No bolt-hole out o' this.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I'm countin' to’three...One... Zachry about to let go, looks down at Meronym, blood oozi from between his clenched fists. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Two... A sudden flash of Autua’s bloody hands bursts before him. Zachry whispers to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: “Hands’a’bleedin’, mus’nt let go.”

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Three! Old Georgie’s eyes bore into him.  149.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: No! He heaves on the rope. Old Georgie’s angry scream becomes the furious wind as ti resumes and Zachry hauls Meronym to safety.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Thank you, Zachry. That’s a bleary fearsome wind. They stand close enough to feel the warmth of each other’ body.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: We best keep moving. INT. AYRS’ CHATEAU - FROBISHER’S ROOM - NIGHT - YEAR 1931 Frobisher is packing furiously. The gun is on the bed. He is so intent on what he is doing, he doesn’t notice th door swing open revealing Ayrs, still in his bed-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: What are you doing, boy? Frobisher is startled. AYRS (CONT’D) I thought I made myself clear.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Do what you want, but I’m leaving. He packs the last of his things. AYRS sees the manuscript for the Sextet.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Fine, Frobisher. Go. But I’11 take this. He snatches the sheaf of papers. Frobisher feels as if he just tore the heart from his chest.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Give me that!

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Consider it redress for what you’ve put me and my family through.  150.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I’m warning you, old man--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Under the conditions of this relationship, I am certainly within my legal rights. If I were you, I’d pack my bag and go.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Goddamn you! He grabs the gun from the bed and thrusts it at AYRS. FROBISHER (CONT’D) Give it to me or I swear to god, I will kill you as you stand. Ayrs steps towards the barrel of the gun.

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Give me the gun, Frobisher--

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I’11 kill you--

dialogues.speaker: AYRS
dialogues.text: Please. You’re a degenerate and a coward. You won’t pull that trigger. Your kind never does. He continues to move closer until he grabs hold of the gu

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: No! The men begin to fight for control of the weapon until-- It goes off, the sharp metal clap startling both of them- The shell of the bullet bouncing on the wood floor with t sound of a delicate chime. It rolls under the bed, where we can see the feet of the men. Ayrs staggers back from Frobisher. Blood drips on to the floor. Ayrs crumples to his knees as Frobisher shuffles, grabbin his things and the manuscript and then runs. As we pan with him we see a tattered book wedged under th short bed-post--  151. It is the lost half of the “Pacific Journal Of Adam Ewing INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S CABIN - DAY - YEAR 1846 Goose enters Adam’s quarter’s. Adam looks like a breathin corpse. Goose searches for a moment. He tries to open a metal lock box but he needs a key. Adam stirs.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: How fares our worm today Adam?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: +-.I’m afraid it has taken the best of me.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Nonsense. He examines him, looking into his eyes. GOOSE (CONT’D) Although I must admit, this treatment is going on much longer than I anticipated. Perhaps it is time for one big dose, full strength and finish this once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enforcer bullet cars surround the transport. In tactical formation, they attack, ripping open the door and penetrating the truck bay while-- Chang lifts his arms in confused hysteria.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Nong-ire! Nong-ire!

dialogues.speaker: LEAD ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Scan him. Another Enforcer aims a scanner and a red beam sweeps acr Chang.

dialogues.speaker: SCAN ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Negative sir. Definite illegal.  152. He speaks loudly and slowly.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Do-You-Have-Work-Visa! Work-Visa! The scanner continues to sweep the room, the beam closes on Sonmi’s hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Magha-lung, hun sugh ja-Visa!

dialogues.speaker: LEAD ENFORCER
dialogues.text: What the fuck is he saying? Does someone have a transcom?

dialogues.speaker: SCAN ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Sir! Second life form!

dialogues.speaker: LEAD ENFORCER
dialogues.text: What? Where? Before he can answer Chang attacks, every move like the c metallic, precision of a chambering bullet-- The gun taped to the back of his neck, ripped free-- Exploding dum-dum bullets transforming faces into meaty carmine anemones. The back-up Enforcers counter but Chang is impossibly fas leaping for cover, closing with predatory focus as they panic, praying and spraying wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are listening to the firefight on their com-link.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Status! Squad Leader report! Do you require assistance? What’s happening down there? More gunshots and screams. ENFORCER PILOT #1 (CONT’D) Fuck this. Light ‘em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hovercraft opens fire, their weapon like an anti-airc cannon combined with a chain gun.  153. The destructive force shatters the high density tube and reduces the transport to alpine swiss. Chang covers Sonmi protecting her with his own flesh as t can do nothing but hope for it to end. Finally it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The co-pilot checks his scanners.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: I got nothing sir. No movement. Six dead Enforcers and-- wait! I got movement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang hoists a home-made rocket launcher from the crate t his shoulder. Before the hovercraft reacts, he stands and fires out the hole blown in the side of the truck and the tube. The pilot tries to dodge the missile but the tail is hit, exploding, sending the hovercraft into a wild spinning descent.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER PILOT
dialogues.text: Mayday! Mayday! We are hit! Going down! The terrorist is still at large! Chang tosses the rocket launcher and reaches for Sonmi wh too stunned to even move.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Commander Hae-Joo Chang. First Science Officer of the Union Rebellion.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Because I believe that you have the power to change this world. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But to do that, I have to keep you alive. We must go. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door that has not been opened for a century cracks slow Dust immediately rises up in agitation. Meronym uses a glo-light as she leads Zachry into the facility. An ancient security guard sits like a mummy, perfectly preserved, his eyeless eyes staring at them as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Before the Fall, the Old Uns built dwellins beyon’a sky, ‘mong the stars. They used this place to send messages there.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Like a prayer t’Sonmi?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Yay.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Is that why we come? To send a prayer?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Yay.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What do a Prescient need t’pray for?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Same thing a Valleysman prays for. She looks at him. MERONYM (CONT’D) Help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deirdre, a sexless automaton, is watching the home shoppi channel on a flickering television.  155. She reaches for her cell phone to buy a commemorative Princess Di plate, when a frantic Veronica rounds the cor

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Hurry! They’re going to kill each other! Deirdre lunges from her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish and Ernie stand, snarling at one another, betwe them each with unbudging grip on a single chocolate puddi cup. A crowd has gathered.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: I’m warning you, Cavendish! Get yer fuggin’ hands offa my pudding cup!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: “Your” pudding cup!? You’ve already eaten yours, you Alzheimer’s riddled lout!

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: You ate my Jell-o yesterday! A deal’s a deal!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I never agreed to those terms!

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Leggo, ya’ dos cunt!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Never! Deirdre and Veronica cut through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Alright you two-- As she moves to separate them, all Hell breaks loose. Ernie grabs a condiment cup of mustard from his tray and shoves it hard into Cavendish’s face. Cavendish screams.  156.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: AAAAAAAGGGGHHH-- Hot Dijon!!!! My eyes!!! Help--Somebody help me!!! Cavendish sinks his teeth into Ernie’s hand still clutchi the cup of pudding. Ernie screams. They grapple as Deirdre tries to wedge herself between th two. Tables and chairs topple in the fracas when finally the help of a couple of orderlies they are separated, huf and puffing. As they are dragged away they both surreptitiously look b to Veronica, who signals to them with a gentle swipe of a finger across the bridge of her nose. They look at each other and smile. Veronica turns to leav her hand slipping Deirdre’s cell phone into her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang, his body laid out as though riding a high-powered motorcycle, weaves the Enforcer bullet car through the thickening traffic. Sonmi lays on top of him, her eyes bulging as they barely miss several vehicles. Behind them several hovercrafts closing fast. Chang taps his com-link implant.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: This is Prophet One. Abort. Repeat- Abort. He clicks the link off.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What did that mean?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: There was a plan. But that plan is fucked.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Everything I can.  157. The car swerves through a tube flowing in the opposite direction-- Banking away into a tangle of buildings as the hovercraft lose sight of them for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dives the bullet car down through a “cargo tube” where large, slow vehicles transport goods. He slips and slides through them, moving like a mouse try to stay out of sight but no matter where he goes-- He is still stuck in a hamster tube. A hovercraft sights him and again the Enforcers converge. Accelerating, he hits an intersection and banks like a lu sled-- Heading into a building’s docking bay-- Disappearing from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several gates are blocking the way but Chang opens fire, car’s guns shredding most of the obstacles-- Aiming the car straight into the blasted roller doors.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Hang on. She squeezes tightly to him as they impact-- Crashing through the doors into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several of the larger hovercrafts set down, Enforcers beetling out, swarming around the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing open the bullet car sleeve, Chang helps Sonmi cra out of the wreckage.  158.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using their scanners, the Enforcers search the building.

dialogues.speaker: SCAN ENFORCER
dialogues.text: We’re close. I got them. In there! They burst into a room, vision-goggles illuminating the d room where they find Sonmi. She raises her hands as they scream at her, aiming their weapons--— Not paying attention to the shadow moving behind them. Chang attacks, killing several with his hands, the last t with a gun.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: In here. Enforcers react to the violence swarming towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang leads her into a bathroom. He checks the walls with orison orb, then pulls out his gun. He opens fire on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enforcers hear the gunfire and race towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large Pvc pipe has a hole blown in it. Vapors that burn Sonmi’s eyes pour out of it.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What is that? Chang looks into it. Far below black water ripples.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Our way out. He yanks off the hidden flak jacket. CHANG (CONT’D) It’s a sewer overflow. Whatever you do, don’t open your eyes or your mouth. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold your breath as long as you can. I’1l find you and get you out. They can hear the boots of the Enforcers.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you trust me? She nods. He jumps into the tube and disappears. A moment later the is a thick splash. The sides of the pipe drip with feces. The smell is overwhelming. The Enforcers find the room as she is still clambering in the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ENFORCER
dialogues.text: Don’t move! She lets go-- Falling down into a shit-lined abyss until-- Splash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa jolts awake. Her car still sinking; the water seeping in through the windows, is filled to her waist. She tries not to panic. She grabs the handle of the windo and starts unrolling it. As she does the water begins pouring in. Very quickly the water rises to her chest. The window is only open six inches when-- The handle snaps off. She screams. The water keeps pouring in. She climbs over to the other door and starts trying to un that window. The water rises past her neck. The handle gets tangled in the seat belt, which floats li an eel.  160. Again frustration and fear shake through her body. The wa rises to her nose as she takes her last breath. Underwater, she grabs the window and yanks and shoves wit all her strength until-- The window breaks. She kicks herself free of the sinking car, her lungs achi kicking up through the cold, silent liquid obsidian until She bursts out the surface.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nay, the dead never stay dead. Open your ears and they never stop a’yibberin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More skeletons, sitting or laying on the floor, as though death caught them by surprise. Their skin, an ancient vel hangs tattered from bony grins. Zachry hears them all whispering his name. Meronym accesses the solar-cells and engages the emergenc power system. Lights flicker on, humming like angry hornets. The room is revealed, including the domed ceiling. Zachry looks up in awe at a mosaic of “Sonmi Among the Stars.”

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Sonmi.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Yay. Tis she. Meronym continues working to try to uplink her orison to main network.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: The Old Uns worshipp’d Sonmi same as Valleysmen? She considers her answer.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Nay, not ‘zactly same as.  161.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Differin’ how? She stops what she is doing.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Do you want the True-true? INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - NIGHT - YEAR Javier peeks around the corner, rises up the stairs and strolls “casually” down to the far end where he checks ar the far corner. Seeing no one he hurries back to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (whispering) All clear. Luisa, still soggy and shivering, slips out of the shadow and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Javier.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No sweat. We’re partners. But you gotta tell me what’s happening. She heads down the hall to her apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: No way. Can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I know it’s something big. Does it have to do with those letters?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Javier--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Come on! You’re in trouble. I can help. I can watch your back, unless you want to keep going for midnight swims. She sighs. He might be able to help or she just doesn’t h the strength to resist him right now.  162.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: All right. Let me take a shower, get some sleep and I’11 tell you what I got in the morning. He shakes his head disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Okay but I hope you realize you just said exactly what every character in any decent mystery says right before they get killed. She opens her door.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Good night Javier. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 She closes the door behind her and puts all three locks o Dropping her bag, she heads straight for the shower, as a shadow crosses behind her-- A man wearing black leather gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown, clumpy filth swirls into the shower drain as rivul of waste run down Sonmi’s body. Numb, she leans in the corner, letting the water pour ove her. Her expression suggests a vague understanding that there things that have happened to her that she will never be a to wash away.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sonmi’s not a god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym chooses her words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: She borned’n’died hundreds o’ years ago on a far’way pen’sula deadlanded now.  163.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I know Valleysman b’liefs’. I know the Abbess teach’d you Sonmi was a mir’cle, birthed o’ the god o’ Smart named Darwin but it ain’t the True-true. Zachry is pacing, a jittery anxiousness bubbling his bloo MERONYM (CONT’D) Her life was sad’n’judased and she died tryin’ to change the Old-Uns thinkin’. Old Georgie emerges behind Zachry from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Liiiiiiies... nothin’ but lies.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Nay... nay, you lyin’. Meronym touches the orison and suddenly Sonmi appears fro the recorder interrogation. Zachry’s eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sonmi...

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: B'fore she died she spoke to an orison ‘bout her acts’n’deedins’. Her words ‘minder’me what’s the True-true. I keep them with me all times.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I tell you o’ True-true-- Tha’s jus’a trick! How long you goin’ lissin t’this?! How long you goin’ jus’ stand there an’let a stranger keep fuggin’ your b’liefs up’n’down’n in’n’out! His hand tightens around the hilt of his spiker.  164. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 As Luisa reaches for the light switch, the gloved man eme from the shadows and grabs her from behind, covering her mouth. She tries to scream but it’s too late. Napier holds Luisa tight.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: If I was trying to kill you, you’d already be dead. I swear I’m not going to hurt you. I just want to talk. He slowly starts to relax when she attacks-- Stomping on his foot, smashing the back of her head into face-- He staggers back, his reflexes faster than most, but not enough as-- A switchblade snaps open and is jammed under his neck, ti to his jugular.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Now if I was trying to kill you, you'd already be dead! How’s that feel? Great conversation starter, isn’t it? He starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think it’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: You are Lester Rey’s daughter, that’s for goddamn sure. The mention of her father, catches her off-guard.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: You knew my father?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: He got me my first job on the force.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: You're a cop?  165.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Was.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: What are you doing working for Seaboard?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Same as you, slinging hash for Spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Yeah well, I don’t have to assault people for my job.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: I’m not here for Seaboard. I’m here because of your father. I don’t know if you’1l even believe me, but I came here to tell you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym shuts off the orison, watching Zachry.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: You a’right, Zachry? He nods at her, something primitive and dark hidden behin his eyes. MERONYM (CONT’D) I got to do some sivvin’n’fixin’ on this here smart, okay? He nods again as we reveal Old Georgie whispering in his

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Ohhhhh, yeah... I see now. She goes to the large control panel and uses her orison t begin diagnosing whether it is still operable. Zachry continues to stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see the what’s’what. You ain’t drop that rope cause you’a’lustin’ for that darkly, sweet’meat.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Shut y’hole!  166. Meronym turns. She can tell something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Do you want’a wait ou’side, Zachry?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Nay. I’m fine. Finish your sussin! She returns to her work while trying to keep an eye on hi Old Georgie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, bro. You ain’t the first to judas your people for the flesh of Jezabel. Zachry shoots him a look. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) I cog it all, now. This whore, with her cokeynut skin, and her slywise mask, smilin’n’wormin’ her way into your trust so you bring her here, scavin’n’sivvin for what? For what boy? He leans in close to whisper in Zachry’s ear. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) They want the island. The Prescients want it all. You judasing your kin helpin’ her out. She ain’t your tribe! She ain’t even your color! She ignores your yarns’n’ways, spinnin’n’spoutin her whoahsomse lies and you lap it up. The suspicion that Georgie is right begins to affect Zach OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Yay, you doin’ it again, jus’like you led the Kona to Adam. You weak’n’stoopit, standin’ there like her dog while she springs her trap. You a coward, thru and thru, a soul- stoned coward. The words hiss between his clenched teeth.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: I ain’t a coward.  167.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Ain’t you? Then do sumthin’! Stop her! Take your spiker an’slit her throat. That’s what y’pa’d do. That’s what Adam’d do. Protect your tribe! Kill her! Now, b’fore it’s too late! Sweat dapples his lip. Panic swims in his eyes. He knows has to do something. He rips the spiker from its sheath and stalks up behind Meronym who never sees him coming. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT - YEAR 1974 Luisa removes the switchblade from his throat.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Grimaldi is dead? What about Isaac?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Sachs? Gone. No survivors. Luisa has to sit down. Napier gives her just a brief mome to digest this.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The plane crash was not an accident. Grimaldi was another threat, like Sixsmith, like you, so they took him out.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: (shaken) Why?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Because he believed in nuclear power.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’m not following you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Ultimately Grimaldi was planning to fix the HYDRA reactor. That’s why he was going to Washington. Lloyd Hooks didn’t want that to happen.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Lloyd Hooks?  168.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Nixon’s former “Energy Guru”, now CEO of Seaboard, Incorporated. But apparently running Swannekke isn’t that big a job because he’s still pulling a seven-figure paycheck from his former gig at KMA Consulting.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’ve heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Recently implicated in financing of the military coup of Chile and assassination of Salvatore Allende. Insubstantial evidence. Cleared of charges. Their client list is a who’s who of Big Oil. A shiver runs down her spine as she sees it coming into focus. NAPIER (CONT’D) Yeah, you got that look like your father used to get. You see it, don’t you? They don’t want the reactor to be fixed They want it to fail. They want the explosion, the chaos and carnage and the more deaths the better. They want endless news reports, months of radiation levels, and evacuations because they know, these bastards know, if it is bad enough, it will be the end of nuclear power. And that’s what Big Oil wants. See? This isn’t about one power station; this is about the future of this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry rushes at Meronym, his spiker slashing as she turn He slams her against the wall, the knife tight to her thr

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Stop! He blinks suddenly uncertain now that he is close to her, actually touching her.  169. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Can’t cogg o’ thing, words'’n’worrins like a wasp’s nest poke’d’n’prod’d by you!

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: What’re you o’ fearyin’ Zachry?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: You come elbowin’’n to our life, yibberin’n’yabberin’ ‘bout True- true but never tellin’ the hole true. I wan’to cogg what you doin’! She speaks calmly.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I told you. I come t’send a plea o’ help.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Help o’ what? To steal our land?! To kill’n’slave us all?! What do you want?!

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Same as ev’ry’un wants... a home. One look into her eyes and he knows she is telling the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi stares out the window at the electric urban sprawl.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: A temporary safe-house. We’1l spend the night. Tomorrow I will take you to the General.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: The General?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: The leader of the Union Rebellion.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What does he want with me? Chang stands beside her.  170.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: He believes the key to over-— throwing this government is the ascendency of a Fabricant. Such an event would destroy one of Unanimity's core belief; that a clone’s life is worth less than a Pureblood. She looks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Is that what you believe? He steps close to her, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: No... that’s not something I believe. It’s something I know. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 Luisa sits on that stool in her hallway and stares Napier down.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: How do I know you’re not lying to me? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: You’re Lester Rey’s daughter. He could smell bullshit a mile away. She takes a moment before asking the next question.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Do you think they will... try again?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: I know they will.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’ve got friends on the force.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Won’t matter. In this business we got a saying, “Everybody crosses the street.” She imagines what that means.  171.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: What do you think I should do?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: If you’re smart, you’ll take my advice: pack your bags, go to the airport, pick somewhere very far away and start over. He reaches under his coat to the small of his back and pu out a gun. NAPIER (CONT’D) Problem is you’re not smart. You’re Lester Rey’s daughter which means you’re gonna do something stupid. I assume you know how to use one of these? She watches herself take the gun as if it were someone el NAPIER (CONT’D) I doubt it will help but it might give you a fighting chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meronym has part of the control board working.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Cross’ur fingers’n’toes. She waves her fingers above the shimmering light projecte the orison air-port connected to the main board. Lights flash and blink. An alarm sounds and Zachry gets nervous like a horse in a thunder storm. Deep inside the bowels of the building, machinery rumbles waking geared golem shrugging off an eon of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top of the station opens a series of spheres inside o spheres, layers of an onion, that rachet back, reversing itself as each becomes the underside of an enormous satel dish.  172.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine whines down as it finishes beaming its gamma message.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Is it done? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Now we jus’a hope we ain’t alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand as silhouettes against the cacophony of kaleidoscopic light.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Are you all right? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I am... afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Of what? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: To ask you for something? He waits standing close enough to feel her breath on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it is forbidden... I have never been kissed. He takes her face in his hands and kisses her, tenderly. Her head swims.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Do you know how long I have wanted to do that? She shakes her head. CHANG (CONT’D) Too long.  173. She kisses him back like someone taking their first drink water after being lost in a desert. They help with each other’s clothes until they are both naked. She realizes something and it stops her.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I have never seen a pureblood naked. You're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: So are you. A lightness fills her heart and she kisses him again. The begin to make love in the glow of the twinkling lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rise is so beautiful from the top of the tower, Frobisher feels his eyes softening to tears.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sixsmith, Don’t worry, all is well. All is so perfectly, damnably well! Wish I could make you see this brightness. I climb the steps of the Bruges tower every morning and all becomes clear. As the sun reaches her pink fingers into the sky, the dis sounds of the waking city become the music Frobisher hear his head; his Sextet. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 Luisa lays on her couch, re-reading Frobisher’s letter.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Boundaries between noise and sound are conventions. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 Ewing shivers and writhes, his sweating flesh twisted int agonizing knots. Goose watches from the shadowed doorway as if enjoying a of art, a Romantic era depiction of suffering.  174.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All boundaries are conventions, waiting to be transcended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry and Meronym begin their descent.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One may transcend any convention if only one can first conceive of doing so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the middle of the night. Cavendish is dressed and packing his bag-- Placing inside with care, “Half-Lives; A Luisa Rey Myster

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At moments like this, I can feel your heart beating as clearly as I feel mine own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi and Chang make love.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --.and I know that separation is an illusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the ceramic St. George and the Dragon. It is the same as the one in Ayrs’ music room.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My life extends far beyond the limitations of me. Frobisher looks at the knight. The silence aches in his ears. When he looks up, he sees Young Sixsmith step into the sh He is so startled that he drops the knight.  175. When it hits, instead of the noise of shattering glass, t is beautiful music, an august melody. Frobisher cocks an eyebrow. A statue of a boy playing attracts him. He nudges it off the shelf. Again there is music. Sixsmith smiles and he pushes a vase. The music swells into a sweeping symphony as they destroy entire shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixsmith wakes from his dream. The crew is ringing the re bell as they prepare to dock in Bruges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a newspaper. The article headline reads, “Maestr Recovering. Assailant Still At Large.” Frobisher sneers.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Maestro, my ass. As he takes a sip of coffee he looks out across the crowd square and sees- Two police officers heading towards the cafe. Hiding behind his paper he waits for them to pass. When t do, he quickly slips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi follows Chang through the crowded checkpoint. Like Tijuana, people are allowed easy access for leaving the Conurb; Sonmi sees the heavily armed Enforcers on the oth side of the fence. A noxious maze of low, crooked ramshacks, flophouses, pawnshops, drug bars, and comfort hives, covering perhaps five square miles southeast of Old Seoul Transit Station. Its streets are narrow, choked with pedestrians and bicyc its alleys reek of waste and sewage. Purebloods slump in doorways, their skin ravaged by the acid rain. A BEING th looks like a child laps water from a dirty puddle.  176.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Stay close to me. Fabricants often get snatched here.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Slave labor. Sex trade. Anything and everything.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: This is where your General lives? Chang smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: This is where Union was born. INT. MADAME OVID’S - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Close as a scalpel slices along the tip of Sonmi’s index finger. She inhales sharply. The implanter digs into her finger and removes a strip of nanotech.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: IMPLANTER
dialogues.text: Your identity. He takes another strip from his tray and sticks it into t bloody slice. Sonmi reacts, but it’s over quickly as he sprays her fing with coag stopping the bleeding immediately.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Who am I now?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Who would you like to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D-Day. Everything is quiet as the staff finish “lights ou A dark figure moves lithely across the grounds.  177.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When The Ghastly Ordeal of Timothy Cavendish is turned into a film, I advise thee, Director dearest, whom I picture as an intense, turtlenecked Swede named Lars, when casting the part of the hero of this tale, one Timothy Cavendish, please make sure the thespian in question is classically trained. I’m thinking Sir Laurence Olivier with a dash of Michael Caine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish coolly enters the boiler room carefully looking back one final time to make sure he wasn’t followed. Ernie checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Last chance to back out if you don't think you can hack it.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I've never backed out of anything in my life. Ernie smiles then turns and unscrews the ventilation unit pulling Deirdre's mobile telephone from its hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Well let’s hear the master bullshitter work his magic. The number in the display stares up at him and he hits se A sleepy voice answers.

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Whatizzit?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, Mr. Hotchkiss?

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Speaking. You are? Cavendish smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Dr. Conway, Aurora House. I'm covering for Dr. Upward.  178.

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus, has something happened to Mother?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, Mr. Hotchkiss. You must steel yourself, I don't think she'll make it to the morning. If you'd like to say goodbye, I suggest you come quickly. INT. MADAME OVID’S - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 A pair of laser pliers are used to cut through the collar encircling Sonmi’s neck. It comes off and Sonmi feels a vertigo spin through her b She touches her own neck for the first time in her life. she does, we notice a comet-shaped birthmark that was hid beneath the collar. Chang smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: How’s that feel?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Strange... frightening but... good.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: That’s it. You’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: To meet the General. There is a knock at the door. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT - YEAR 1973 Luisa opens the door revealing Javier who smiles as brigh the sun.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: So you survived the night. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever go to school?  179.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Walt Whitman dropped out of Elementary school. Ditto Mark Twain. There’s no winning against Javier.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: What do you want for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Grape nuts. Banana if you got it. He comes in, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang knocks on a door hidden at the end of a nameless al The electric eye in the door opens, staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: It’s Chang. After a moment of deliberation, the door unbolts and open A large man who could be a Fabricant, escorts them inside Sonmi sees the gun bulging under his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang and Sonmi enter and are escorted through a maze of smoky rooms filled with ugly faces floating above their clattering tiles. Their escorts are wearing blood stained body armor yet no blinks an eye. In a back room the door is bolted. An ancient brazier hums with modern circuity. A sphere of dark sheen and refracted silence aquifies all the surroun noise. In the center of the room a young boy appears, like a gho His voice is that of an old man.

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: Sonmi-451. I am sorely thankful to see you still alive and truly honored to meet you. I am General An-Kor Apis, leader of Union.  180. Unsure how to react, Sonmi bows. AN-KOR APIS (CONT’D) I apologize for the Sim-com but my advisors assure me it is a necessary precaution. I am also forced to be brief. I know you have many questions but let me begin with the how. Sonmi stares through the light gauze of smoke. AN-KOR APIS (CONT’D) Years ago a psychogenomicist named Yusouf Suleiman proved that Fabricants were capable of the same consciousness as any Pureblood. He was rewarded for the discovery of this scientific truth with imprisonment, execution and the eradication of any evidence suggesting the success of his experiment. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY - YEAR 1973 Javier sits on the couch, crunching Grape nuts.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: So, do you know who did it? Luisa is making a fruit salad in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Did what?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Who tried to off ya?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Javier--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: What? It’s the truth, ain’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: It’s not what I want to talk about right now. He looks at the letters spread out on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Are they after these letters?  181.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: It’s... complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General lights a cigarette, the real and virtual smok layering on each other.

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: A high ranking genomicist inside the Ministry of Science and Commerce is sympathetic to our cause. It was he that supplied us with Suleiman’s formula. The rest of the details are superficial; the use of shells and intrigues to secure a legitimate research license, as well as the necessary front to instream the catalyst at Papa Song, all made legal by the unwitting help of a University doctoral candidate.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Boom-Sook.

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: An unfortunate bit of collateral damage. I’m afraid the success of your sentience caught us all off guard.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: ++.and Yoona?

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: A tragedy to be sure, that will be remembered only with the success of our Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: General Apis... I am just a dinery server. I was not genomed to alter history.

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: No revolutionary ever was.  182.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish is standing sentinel in Mr. Meeks's room watchi his own room just across the hall through the crack in th door.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ernie’s plan was a series of toppling dominoes. The first of which had fallen predictably and flawlessly. But the third was a crapshoot and could fall in unwelcome directions. At a quarter past ten Ernie went to Reception to announce my death to Nurse Noakes. The big unknown lay in Nurse Noakes's personal loathing for me. Would she rush to see her enemy fallen, to stick a hatpin in my neck to check I was truly dead? Or celebrate in style first? Mr. Meeks watches over Cavendish’s shoulder as hurried so soled footsteps echo in the hall. Nurse Noakes stops in f of Cavendish’s room, collects herself then knocks.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know... She tries the handle, as Cavendish silently hushes him.

dialogues.speaker: NOAKES
dialogues.text: Mr. Cavendish? Is everything alright? Inside she sees an unmoving figure under the blankets. Mr. Meeks rocks excitedly as she steps into the room. He tugs on Cavendish’s sleeve. Cavendish turns and Mr. Meeks leans into his ear whisperi

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: Don’t leave me. Cavendish stunned, stares at the pleading, Mr. Magoo-like eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the men stare at Sonmi, waiting for an answer. Alm imperceptibly, she shakes her head.  183.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I can not do what you are asking. There is a disappointed silence.

dialogues.speaker: AN-KOR APIS
dialogues.text: I understand. It would be a difficult choice for anyone. (beat) But before you call your decision final, there is one last thing I’d like you to see. He crushes out his cigarette. AN-KOR APIS (CONT’D) So you understand fully what we are fighting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish turns away from the pleading eyes of Meeks with expression that says, “I’m sorry.”

dialogues.speaker: NOAKES
dialogues.text: Mr. Cavendish? Across the hall, Noakes switches on the lights. Something about the way the figure looks arouses her suspicion and she crosses to the bed-- Cavendish leaps from Meeks’ room lunging for the door han He yanks the door shut but not before Nurse Noakes grabs stopping it from closing. Noakes snarls at him.

dialogues.speaker: NOAKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew it was too good to be true.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: You’1l find my comment card on my nightstand, but don’t expect very favorable marks, you cantankerous witch. They both strain against the handle, Cavendish’s grip slipping slightly. Realizing he is about to lose the tug of war, Cavendish gambles and lets go of the door.  184. Nurse Noakes not expecting the sudden lack of resistance flies head over heels onto the floor. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) And so adieu. The literal translated from the French meaning to commend before-- She bull-rushes the door-- But Cavendish quickly scurries slamming it shut rushing through his speech. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) God. Her fists and catalog of threats beat at the door much to Meeks’ delight. Cavendish flicks the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a furious pounding on the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing! Mr. Ewing! I must speak with you! Open this door-- The door cracks open revealing Frobisher.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I asked you not to disturb me!

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: I do apologize, Mr. Ewing but this is a matter of serious consequence.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Yes. Go on then.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: It seems the local constable is rather vexed, searching as he is, high and low for this dangerous ruffian who attacked the great composer Vyvyan Ayrs. Have you seen the papers, Mr. Ewing? It’s quite a scandal. Sensing where this is going, Frobisher shakes his head. HOTEL MANAGER (CONT’D) You’re a composer, yourself aren’t you? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOTEL MANAGER (CONT’D) They say this, Robert Frobisher, that’s his name, is also a composer-

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: The constable asked to search my rooms. I know how hard you are working so I told him there was no one on the third floor. It costs quite a bit of money to keep an entire floor empty. Frobisher pulls out his purse and empties it.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: That’s everything I have. He takes the money, admiring Frobisher’s waistcoat.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: That is the most beautiful waistcoat... Frobisher begins removing it while the manager smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, you think these letters are the key? INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY - YEAR 1973 Luisa pours herself a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: No. Not really. Javier is still on the couch, looking intently at the letters.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: But the old guy had these letters the night they offed him, so they gotta be important.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: They were to him. Luisa grabs a spoon for her fruit salad.  186.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: But if they’re not important why do you keep reading them? He notices something and picks up a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I don’t know... maybe I’m just trying to understand something. He begins scribbling with the pencil.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Why we keep making the same mistakes over and over. She crosses to the couch with her salad and her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Maybe you should ask Megan. She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Do you know a Megan?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
