dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s his niece. But how did you know that? I didn’t tell you that? He holds up the back of the envelope that he was rubbing pencil against, highlighting, “Megan Sixsmith” and her Ha address.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Looks like he mailed her something the night he died. Probably used the envelope he was keeping these letters in. Her jaw is on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, Luisa. First rule of mystery writing: a good clue always leads to another clue.  187. She rushes at him, kissing him, grabbing the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Javier, you're a fucking genius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hotchkiss’ Range Rover roars through the automatic ga Johns Hotchkiss's wife in the driving seat. As they pass by, Ernie grabs a chain and loops it around gate, stopping it from being able to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish watches on the surveillance camera. As the car pulls up, Veronica rushes to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Mr. Hotchkiss? Your mother is my dearest friend here. Do hurry to her, please. The doctor thought it too dangerous to move her. Johns Hotchkiss’ wife grabs him and hauls him into the building.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: It’s working. I can’t believe it’s working. He ducks just as they rush by heading up the stairs. As s as they are out of sight, Cavendish bolts outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavendish climbs behind the wheel of the luxury SUV. It h been a while. He tries to re-acclimate himself with the basics while Er heaves their suitcases haphazardly into the back.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Right. Yes, I see-- No, wait-- Ah!-- No... Veronica’s door slams as Ernie jumps into the passenger s He looks at Cavendish. Cavendish nods and reaches for the key in the ignition.  CAVENDISH (CONT’D) I-- I don’t--

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: No key. Cavendish starts to panic. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) No ruddy key--

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: He always leaves it in the ignition!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: His wife was driving! She took the keys! The ruddy female took the keys in with her! Sweet Saint Ruddy Jude, what do we do now? 188. Ernie looks on the dashboard, in the glove compartment, o the floor. CAVENDISH (CONT’D) Can you hot-wire it?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Don't be soft!

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Think of something! You’re the genius! You’re the ruddy ruddy genius! They see Withers running down the nightlit corridor from dining room annex, with two Hotchkisses close behind.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Shite! Ernie punches the automatic locks.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: We’re done for! EXT. LUISA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY - YEAR 1973 Luisa exits the building. She checks her watch, then hurr down the sidewalk.  189. We watch her from inside a car. A pair of gloved hands ta hold of the steering wheel. The driver pulls the car out begins to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Withers flings open the front door leaping down the steps

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Look under the sun flap! Cavendish pulls down on the visor, the Range Rover key dropping into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE/CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Yeeeeee-sss! Cavendish sees them coming fast his fingers fumbling drop the key. Withers flies head-over-ass on a frozen puddle-- Just as Cavendish bangs his head on the steering wheel, t horn sounding.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Hurry, Tim, hurry! Withers yanks at the locked door.

dialogues.speaker: WITHERS
dialogues.text: I’m gonna flay your arse straight into a coma if you don’t open this door, Cavendish! The Hotchkisses surround their car, as Cavendish drives t key home into the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS
dialogues.text: Get your bony carcasses out of my car or I'll sue — Dammit, I'll sue anyway! The SUV roars to life, dashboard blazing with fairy light Chet Baker singing "Let's Get Lost.” Cavendish cranks the gearshift and the SUV leaps forward. He chuckles as he sees them recede in the rearview mirror but his smile quickly fades when he catches the figure of Meeks shuffling out of the vestibule.  190.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Oh look, it’s Mr. Meeks. Cavendish looks back and then ahead at the wide open gate He groans.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Oh ruddy, bloody hell. He cranks the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? Are you daft man?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I can’t do it. The SUV arcs onto the lawn, four wheel drive ripping into turf, Cavendish leaving his mark; a giant “C”-- And they lurch back toward Aurora House the Hotchkisses a Withers scattering out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: All for one and one for all, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Veronica would you unlock the door for Mr. Meeks? The SUV bounds up the walk fishtailing and skidding to a parallel to the door. Mr. Meeks shuffles in place in excitement, as Veronica opens the side door.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Meeks! We’re out for a night time drive.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know! I know! The car lunges forward again barreling at Hotchkiss who t to stand his ground but at the last moment, he leaps away They chortle until they realize what Withers is doing; th chain is in his hands, the heavy gate swinging closed.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What now?  191.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Ram the gates.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Nice big Range Rover at fifty miles per hour should do the trick. So long as the center pole isn't sunk deep, the gates'll just fly apart on impact.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: And if it is sunk deep?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Then we'll fly apart on impact. So, foot to the floor, Cavendish! Cavendish goes white, his life suddenly up for review.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: How terribly thrilling! The gates rush at them, ten, eight, six car lengths away. Cavendish whispers to himself.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Sod it, Timbo, what have you got to lose? He jams his foot down on the accelerator and-- Wham! The vertical bars become diagonal ones as-- The gates fly off their hinges. Cavendish’s heart bungee-jumps from throat to bowel and b again as he grips his intestines shut with all his might. The Range Rover bucks and skids all over the road rubber tries burning but -- Somehow manages to stay out the ditch and upright. Fog undulates in the headlight beams.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We made it?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Absolutely thrilling!

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know, I know! Cavendish stomps on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: All for one and one for all! Mr. Meeks giggles humming "The British Grenadiers" as the Range Rover wolfs down the northward miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa hurries down the street, heading for a small intersection of a large street and a much smaller warehou street. As she steps off the curb, a black car waiting down the throat of the small street peels out. Luisa is on the middle of the street when she realizes wh is about to happen-- She looks like she is ready to die until-- She whips out a gun and fires into the windshield. The car swerves, bounces off another parked car and almos hits her when-- Napier tackles her, knocking her to the ground as-- The black car bashes its way into crossing traffic.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: It worked.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Like hell it did. He’s supposed to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I told you I’m a terrible shot. Tires scream as the black car swerves through traffic.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Shit. Come on.  193.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: He’s coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry and Meronym react to a loud sound.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Kona war cry. Comin’ from the Valley. They hear the shrieking cry again. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Oh no-no-no-- mercysome Sonmi, please, no. He bolts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonmi stares ahead looking at something that frightens he

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: This is what the General wanted me to see? Chang nods. From a hidden vantage point, they are looking at an enorm freighter, the size of a battleship. The ship’s call letters are stenciled along the prow: GEO-R93. Emblazoned upon its severely distressed hull we also see bright, cheerful logo of Papa Song Inc. A transport arrives and Sonmi watches as several of her Fabricant sisters, including a few Sonmis, cluster excite

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They believe they are going to Xultation.  194. She looks at Chang. SONMI-451 (CONT’D) But they’re not, are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry races desperately, tearing through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa and Napier run as the black car closes after them.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The end rushes towards me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher’s pen quivers furiously, moving to the rush of music pouring out of him like blood from an open vein.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ayrs has the dogs after me. The bullet passed through killing little more than his appetite yet he’s out for blood. Will have to pay the piper eventually but not now. Now all I want is a quiet room where I can finish the Sextet. A plate of food remains untouched. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Unable to eat, or sleep. Like Ewing, the “mortal coil” has become a noose. INT. PAPA SONG’S FRIEGHTER - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Wearing the white robes of the Aides, Sonmi and Chang mak their way down into the ship-- While all around them is a haunting beautiful chorus of singing voices.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Would rather become music. Smiling Fabricants wait in lines, winding like a coiled bowel, singing their Hymns of Freedom and Xultation.  195.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branches slash at his skin and clothes as Zachry reaches perimeter of the village. Smoke turns everything into a k of hazy dream. He runs past a burning house-- On the fence post a severed head cries soundlessly. INT. PAPA SONG’S FRIGHTER - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 Chang leads her to the Observation deck; a series of catw above rows of small, almost empty rooms. In each, there is a chair in the center. Two Aides work e room. Sonmi watches as the next Fabricant in line is escorted i the room. It is a Sonmi model. The second Aide prepares a device that swings around like dentist armed-tool but is shaped like a partial helmet. The Fabricant is seated in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Just relax. This is to remove your collar. The Sonmi beams.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-351
dialogues.text: Just as Papa Song promised. The Aide smiles and nods as the device is fitted to her h The operating Aide hits a button and with a sharp “clack” metal bolt is driven through the center of the Fabricant’ forehead, killing her instantly. With a factory worker’s sense of routine, they finish the work; cleaning the chair, pulling the next helmet into pl while the other one lifts the Sonmi off her feet. She dances in the air, swinging like a side of beef as th conveyered helmet bears her body through a flapped doorwa

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: (whispers) Where are they taking her?  196.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Kona horse remains outside the house. The horse bristle he nears it. He stalks towards the front yard when he sees-- Rose dead, laying in a pool of blood. Like a reoccurring nightmare he cannot escape, he stumble towards her body. Anguish wracks his heart. His only remaining thought is of his niece.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Catkin? INT. PAPA SONG’S SLAUGHTERHOUSE - NIGHT - YEAR 2144 The space is vast, perhaps a third of the belly of the enormous ship; the slaughterhouse sprawls out below them if it had no end. A few workers, and an army of conveyor belt robots wield scissors, sword-saws, and varying tools for stripping, rending and grinding. With assembly-line efficiency, they snip collars, strip clothes, peel skin, offcut hands and feet, and vacuum out offal. It is perhaps the sound that disturbs Sonmi the most.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Recycled Fabricants are a cheap source of protein. The genomics industry demands huge quantities of liquefied biomatter for wombtanks and more importantly to sustain their engineered labor force.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Soap. Chang nods. SONMI-451 (CONT’D) They feed us to ourselves.  197. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 Goose leans in, barely an inch from Ewing’s face. He spea in a loving whisper.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Dearest Ewing, your worm is in its death throes, expelling every drop of poison. Drink this final purgative to expel its calcified remains. Come on, handsomely does it, one last drink, the end of your suffering is at hand. Ewing strains to lift himself, his lips reaching for the alembic. Lightning strikes outside as the ship is rocked by the approaching storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry quietly moves through his abandoned house. Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Catkin? He hears a male voice grumbling. Then, silence again. Someone is still in the house. He holds his spiker ready attack. Stalking through the house, he sees the intruder passed o in the storeroom, having drank all of their dandelion win A KONA WARRIOR. As far as Zachry knows, this is the man who killed his sister. He knows what he is going to do. The spiker flashes as Zachry fits it beneath the warrior’ throat. The blue vein pulses, waiting but something is wrong. The world seems to freeze as Zachry hears the Abbesses wo

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Enemy’s sleepin’, don’t slit that throat.”  198. His mind goes to war with every instinct in his body. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 The dark liquid touches Ewing’s lips just as there is a k on the door. His focus broken, Ewing lays back. Goose is frustrated. T knock continues.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: (through the door) Missa Ewing! Missa Ewing!

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: ..-Autua?

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Adam, you really must drink this. His voice is barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: .-.-please... see what he wants. Grumbling, Goose carefully sets the alembic down. He unlo the door. Autua smiles when he sees Ewing and tries the enter.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing, how are you-- Goose stops him.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing is at a critical juncture in his treatment. The next few hours will determine if he will live or die. Autua realizes the seriousness of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Then I stay here.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: What, no, you can’t.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: I must. Missa Ewing save my life. He my duty.  199.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you ignorant ape, “Missa Ewing” does not want you around him. You probably infected him to begin with. He begged me to please, and I quote, “keep that dirty nigger away from me.” So please, kindly respect his wishes. Autua is too stunned to do anything as Goose slams the do Goose turns already knowing the look of horror upon Ewing face. Ewing’s mouth works uselessly. GOOSE (CONT’D) What’s that, Ewing? How shall I comprehend if you drool and dribble so? He laughs, his mask completely dropped. GOOSE (CONT’D) Let me hazard a guess, then. Something in the key of, “Oh Henry, how could you do this to me? I thought we were friends?” He stoops and picks up the alembic. GOOSE (CONT’D) Unfortunately, you are wrong, Adam. Wrong like Horrox and your silly father-in-law. There is only one rule that binds all people, one governing principle that defines every relationship on God’s green earth. He sits beside Ewing again, his teeth looming over the helpless Ewing. GOOSE (CONT’D) “The Weak are Meat and the Strong Do Eat.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry stares at the Kona, rage and hate boiling his bloo He screams, sinking the knife deep into the warriors thro whose eyes snap open--  200. The blade saws through the gristle of the larynx, blood bubbling as he tries to shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car roars after Napier and Luisa like a predatory ani smashing into dumpsters, sparks flying, metal shrieking-- The front grill of the old sedan gleaming like teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goose presses his knee against his chest, pinning him.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: Why, you ask. He pulls out a pen knife. GOOSE (CONT’D) ‘Tis absurdly simple. Using the knife he slices off a button from Ewing’s lovel waistcoat. He inspects the button, finds it to his liking and smiles, a toothy, yellow smile. GOOSE (CONT’D) There is money in your trunk and I want it, so I have killed you for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Smoke leans out of his window, firing his gun as Nap drags Luisa around a corner-- Into a dead end.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Shit. The car comes screeching around the corner as they race u flight of stairs to a warehouse door. The door opens and they rush inside. Bill Smoke, stops the car and walks briskly after them.  201.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kona lies soaked in his own blood. Zachry suddenly sees movement in the corner of the room. floor is moving ever so softly. Slowly, he sneaks closer. There’s a secret door in the ground, hard to identify as blends in with the earth and dust around it. His spear ready to be thrown, he yanks it open-- Revealing Catkin, trembling with fear, hiding in a little hole underneath the door. They fall into each other’s arms, tears flooding down the faces, when they hear more horses. Zachry ducks and crawls to the window. Four more KONA are gathered around the empty horse. They begin calling a name. Whistling. Zachry looks at the dead man. Catkin sees him, too. Zachr hushes her back into her den. When he looks back out the window he sees the Kona coming towards the house. He looks for a place to hide; slithering into a cupboard as two of the Kona enter. Immediately they find the body. Zachry listens to their angry shouts; boots begin pounding through the house. The darkness of his cramped box is filled with the sound violence as the warriors tear through, smashing and destroying what little the Bailey’s owned. From the crack of light and the proximity of sound, he kn one of them is just outside the door. He holds his breath. He prays. It is not enough-- The cupboard opens; the moment their eyes meet, Zachry kn he is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sparse reception area is lit by a single tube, a tomb o flies. A black-eyed young Mexican woman swoops from nowhe and flutters into Napier’s face brandishing her nail-file  202.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: No ‘llegals here! No ‘llegals here! Bossaway! Bossaway! Come back ‘notherday! The noise from the back is monolithic.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: I’m not an inspector. We need help. A poodle wanders out of its cardboard bed and begins snif at Napier. The woman responds with machine-gun Spanish, talking to Napier and the dog simultaneously. NAPIER (CONT’D) I don’t understand-- Luisa jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: (in perfect Spanish) We don’t want the police to get involved. We understand your situation but there is a man you is trying to kill me and we really need your help. The woman looks at her, unsure of what she should do. INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 Goose smiles, pinching Ewing’s nose, forcing his mouth op

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: I commend you for a noble constitution, Adam. Most of my patrons succumb to my ministrations long before it comes to a drama such as this, but enough’s enough, it is time for you to die. He holds the alembic to his lips and begins to pour. The lantern sways nervously as the wind howls and rain la the ship. The poison fills Ewing’s mouth when the door explodes ope Autua steps into the room; a club in his clenched fist.  203.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Get away from Mr. Ewing or I kill you. Goose rises affably.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: This is a simple misunderstanding-- He attacks, throwing the alembic but Autua is too fast-- Closing the distance, bashing Goose in the face, shatteri his nose. Goose goes down in the cramped space as Ewing spits the poison from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: Mr. Ewing. Autua rushes to Ewing. AUTUA (CONT’D) Gotta flush you out. He starts to lift him, when Ewing sees--— Goose rise up, blood streaming from his ruined nose, his like a rabid dog about to attack--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Smoke shoves through the door, into the small recept area. Napier and Luisa are gone. There are three doors in the room. The Mexican flaps her hands with her long elaborately pai nails at him as if shooing flies, mixing Spanish and heav accented English.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: Two people came in here, which way did they go? Her poodle becomes immediately agitated and begins barkin

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: We treat workers good! (more Spanish) No need Union! (more Spanish) Smoke pulls out his gun.  204.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: Which way did they go? The gun sends her into hysterics. The dog gets even more upset. Combined with the roar of the hidden machines, Smo can’t hear himself think. SMOKE (CONT’D) Shut up! Shut the fuck up! The yapping of the dog is like aluminium on teeth. She is telling him who her boss knows when-- He shoots the dog. She freezes, too shocked to even understand. SMOKE (CONT’D) Stupid fucking wetback. She sinks to her knees, crying out in terrible pain while pushes past her and enters the third door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry is thrown onto the ground. His hands are bound beh him, Rose laying a few feet away. An angry tattooed warrior puts a boot to his neck.

dialogues.speaker: KONA WARRIOR
dialogues.text: For what you done, we ought blade off your hands’n’feet, blade off your cock an leave you for the flies’n’rats’ feastin’. But Captain say that too good for you. Another Kona finishes heating a branding iron. Zachry sees the orange-red glowing piece of metal and beg to struggle. Zachry screams as the brand is pressed deep into his chee INT. THE PROPHETESS - EWING’S ROOM - DAY - YEAR 1846 Goose attacks, shrieking like an animal bashing Autua who collapses onto Ewing. Before Goose can finish the job, the ship heaves violentl throwing everyone against the far wall.  205. Autua recovers as he and Goose have at one another in the chaos of the rolling, pitching waves and disorienting lam light. Goose flails after several spilled vials from his bag as Autua finds his club and is about to finish the fight but Goose hurls a liquid that burns him. The killer leaps on top, using the club to crush Autua’s pipe. Autua looks past Goose.

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: No, Missa Ewing! Don’t! Get out of here! Goose smiles, blood smeared across his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GOOSE
dialogues.text: You got a lot to learn about lying, nigger. Ewing can’t even stand, let alone help you-- But Ewing is standing and more than that, he raises the metal lock box that Goose wanted and-- Swings with every fibre of his being, falling as he strik The sound of metal breaking against bone like a crack of thunder as-- Goose collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A noose hangs around Zachry’s neck, tying him to the back the Kona’s horse. The body of the man he killed is tied o the horse beside him. He seems almost resigned to his fate when he sees the Kon throw a torch onto the thatched roof. It immediately bursts into flames. Terror clutches his heart.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Catkin. Fire and smoke consume the small house as Zachry writhes.  206. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Oh no. S’my fault. S’all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An underworld sweatshop clattering with five hundred sewi machines. Flakes of textile are suspended in the viscous heat, haloing the naked bulbs hanging over each machinist Luisa and Napier skirt the outer walkway in a rapid semi- crouch. Limp Donald Ducks and crucified Scooby-Doos have their innards stitched, one by one, row by row, pallet by pallet. Each woman keeps her eyes fixed on the needle pla so Luisa and Napier cause little commotion. They enter a large storeroom. Rows, aisles and ten-foot t boxes conceal the true dimensions of the room. Napier is considering if they should go back when gunshot make up his mind. They weave through the maze of cardboard as Smoke chases, firing his gun. A door opens to a stairwell down. They leap down the sing flight to a mechanical service tunnel. The door of the stairwell bangs above them as Smoke gains. They race down the hall which has several heavy metal doo trying each one. They are all locked. Smoke enters the hall at the other end. There is one last door remaining. Napier grabs the handle-- It’s locked. There’s no way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry thrashes against his ropes, screaming as the house swallowed by flames. The Kona sneer as they mount their horses and dig their s when-- Zachry hears a “ksss-ksss” sound and the warrior falls of his horse-- Two red holes in his forehead.  207. The others react but the sound continues, like bees zippi by-- Two more drop with holes punched through different parts there bodies. The last one slings a rock and Meronym is knocked from he perch in a tree. She falls with a terrible thud, her thin silver weapon bouncing away. Zachry tries to get free but can’t. The Kona grabs the weapon before Meronym can recover. He lifts it, aiming it at her and pulls the trigger-- Exploding his own head because he had the futuristic gun backwards. Meronym stands, brushing herself off.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: I’m getting too old for this shit.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Catkin! She’s’n th’house!

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Oh no. There’s not much left of it but she runs straight into th burning house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiming his gun, Smoke walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: I told Grimaldi, you couldn’t be trusted, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Look who’s talking.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: I’m completely loyal to whoever writes the biggest check. That’s the business we’re in.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Maybe I’m tired of the business.  208. He smiles and lifts the gun.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: Well... enjoy your retirement. He is about to shoot when the Mexican woman steps out of alcove leading to one of the other doors. In her hand is a monkey wrench which she brings down on t back of Smoke’s head, crumpling him like a pushed pile of bricks. Ten more blows of extreme ferocity follow, each one makin Luisa flinch.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yo! Amaba! A! Ese! Jodido! Perro! She leans over Smoke’s pulped face. MEXICAN WOMAN (CONT’D) And don’t call me a fucking wetback!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry thrashes off the horse. Using the spurs of the dea Kona, he cuts himself free. Just as he stands, Meronym stumbles out of the collapsing house-- Catkin in her arms. A cry bursts from him like a bird taking flight. He rushe to his sister, engulfing her with his arms. With gratitude wetting his eyes, he looks up at Meronym.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Thank you. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewing vomits salty water on the planks of the “Prophetess

dialogues.speaker: AUTUA
dialogues.text: One more. Salt clean your stomach.  209. Holding Ewing who can barely kneel by himself, Autua forc another liter of salt water into Ewing’s throat, who convulses before spitting it all out again. AUTUA (CONT’D) Good. See where we are, Missa Ewing. He helps Ewing up to stand. With Ewing, we can see the harbour: the boat is docked in San Francisco bay.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: ..-home. The sight of his home bears Ewing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Range Rover hums along the night road. A service stat sign glows up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Alright almost home. The Range Rover’s lights fall on an all-night petrol stat with a pub next door called the Hanged Edward. Midnight i long gone, but the lights are still on. ERNIE (CONT’D) Park in the pub. I'll go and get us a can of petrol so nobody'll spot us. Silly Johns left his jacket in the car, and in the jacket—tra-la. Ernie pulls out a wallet thick with pounds.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: A Drambuie and soda would hit the spot.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sure he can stand us a round.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I must admit in all the excitement I did forget to wee before our escape.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: I know! I know!  210.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the warm cave of a bar, a crowd watches TV soccer in a distant fluorescent time zone. In the eighty-first minute England is a goal down to Scotland. Without taking his eyes off the TV the barman delivers Er their drinks by sense of touch alone. The foursome edge their way through the crowd and take th seats in an alcove. A cyclone of despair suddenly sweeps through the bar as England is awarded a penalty. Tribalism electrifies the air.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: I'd like to check my route. Ernie, the map if you will.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: You had it last.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Oh. Must be in... Cavendish’s face freezes in sudden rigor mortis. CAVENDISH (V.O.) (CONT’D) My room. Extreme close-up, Director Lars, of Cavendish realizing his fateful mistake. I had left the map on my bed. For Nurse Noakes. With our route marked out in felt pen. His face breaks its glacial hold.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +.-oh God. I think we had better drink up and move on.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: But we've only just started this round. Cavendish swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: About the, er, Map... He checks his watch calculating distances and speeds in h head. Ernie begins to catch on.  211.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: What about the map? His mouth opens to speak but the room is drowned in a how tribal grief. England has tied the match. In the din the entrance door opens and the hulking figure Mr. Withers fills the frame. His Gestapo eyes settle on t group as Johns Hotchkiss and an orderly appear beside him Cavendish lets out a breath of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachry rides with Catkin as their horses charge down the in full gallop. As they charge towards the edge of the Valley they pass r by a large party of looting Kona. The Kona are stunned for a moment until the leader bellow

dialogues.speaker: KONA WARRIOR
dialogues.text: After them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veronica sighs a frail sigh as Withers and Hotchkiss surr them.

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS
dialogues.text: Your little joy ride is over. Withers clamps a huge hand on Cavendish’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: WITHERS
dialogues.text: You’re going to be sorry in ways you can’t even imagine.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Oh bother. I had so hoped to see the wild mountain thyme, all across the blooming heather...

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, love. Grimly, Mr. Meeks stands-- and lets out a biblical bellow The TV viewers drop their conversations and look. Even Withers stops in his tracks.  212. Mr. Meeks climbs onto the bar, and roars an SOS to his universal fraternity.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MEEKS
dialogues.text: Are there nor trrruuue Scortsmen in tha hooossse? Ernie, Veronica, and Cavendish’s jaw goes slack. Mr. Meeks points at Withers with a skeletal forefinger. MR. MEEKS (CONT’D) Those there English gerrrrunts are trampling o'er ma God-gi'en rrraights! Theeve used me an' ma pals morst direly an' we're inneed of a wee assistance!

dialogues.speaker: WITHERS
dialogues.text: Come quiet and face your punishments. On hearing Wither’s English accent the room curdles. A ROCKER rises like Poseidon and flexes his knuckles. A C OPERATOR stands beside him. A SHARKY-CHINNED MAN in a thousand-quid suit. An AXWOMAN with the scars to prove it The TV is switched off. A Highlander growls softly.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHLANDER
dialogues.text: Aye, laddie. We'll nort let ye doone. Withers bristles.

dialogues.speaker: WITHERS
dialogues.text: These men are car thieves.

dialogues.speaker: AXWOMAN
dialogues.text: You a copper? She moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us your badge then. He takes a step.

dialogues.speaker: POSEIDON
dialogues.text: Aw, you're full o' shite, man.  213. He leans forward. Hotchkiss has had enough and begins crossing the room whe his path is blocked by a pool cue.

dialogues.speaker: HOTCHKISS
dialogues.text: Now you just look here, you grebo, you can go shag your bloody sporran if you think— Violence erupts, the pub filling with the sound of knuckl and bone on flesh. One of Hotchkiss’ teeth splashes into Cavendish’s Kilmago fifteen feet away. Cavendish fishes it out for a keepsake As the pandemonium escalates, the foursome gulp their dri down then scurry out the back exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bolt sizzles past Zachry’s head. The chasing Kona fire crossbows from their galloping hors Meronym hefts her rifle. The air crackles as she fires tw leaving smoking fist-sized holes in the two slavers. With Catkin holding tight to him, Zachry kicks his horse’ sides as the Kona thunder behind them, in hot pursuit. As their horses clear a ridge we see up ahead the brillia blue Pololu River, where the road pitches down and meets decaying bridge of worn planks and rusting steel. They race for it and as they do the sun clears a cloud ba and the colors of the bridge light up as if aflame in ora and bronze. The Abbess's final prophecy pulses in Zachry’s brain.

dialogues.speaker: ABBESS VOICE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Bridge a’burnin’, your path lies below. He shouts to Meronym.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: We can’t be crossin’ that bridge!

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: What?  214. She twists in the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: We ain’t s’posed to use that bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Over there’s our meetin with the Prescient ship! That bridge ain't safe?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: No. (he can’t explain) Sonmi tell’d me not t’cross it. Meronym’s face crinkles as she stops her horse.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: An'did Sonmi know we got a furyin' swarm o'Kona on our tail?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: We can ford the river down there. He points down a fork in the road where the path meets th water. The hoofs drum louder as the Kona close.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I trus’ you. Now you trus’ me. Meronym makes her decision and follows Zachry down the pa away from the bridge. The footing is slick and rocky though and it slows their flight. As they begin to ford the river, they look back to see th first of the Kona converging on the bridge. The warriors as they see them and raise their crossbows. The water of the Pololu, already up to their horses neck, numbingly cold. Crossbow bolts sizzle angrily around them more Kona horsemen arrive. Zachry curses himself as the Kona charge onto the bridge. Meronym also curses in her own language as she watches th cross with nothing but a slight moan of timber until--  215. Just before they reach the other side, an explosion of tearing, shrieking fibers fills the air, the bridge givin way-- Collapsing under the weight of the war party. The Kona horsemen fall in an avalanche of rent metal and debris plunging to their deaths twenty meters below. Zachry howls, beating the water, standing up on his horse he laughs and bays like a bear that has defended its home

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Megan Sixsmith sits on a low bench in the Buenas Yerbas Museum of Modern Art and stares back at a giant portrait an old lady's ursine face, rendered in interlacing gray a black lines on a canvas otherwise blank. Luisa Rey sits down next to her. She is covered in dirt, grime and blood from the chase.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Megan Sixsmith?

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Luisa Rey? They both nod. MEGAN (CONT’D) Is Joe with you?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: That’s him over there, pretending to be the art lover. He’s watching out for us. I’m afraid his paranoia is justified.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Yes... so you’ll understand why I have to ask you a question. I need to be sure you are who you say you are.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Good. Ask away.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: What was my uncle’s favorite Hitchcock film? Luisa smiles.  216.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’1ll assume he told you that we talked about this in the elevator. Shadow of a Doubt. Though he said he recently watched Psycho with you. Megan smiles at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: He called Janet Leigh a “bubblehead.” Luisa reaches into her bag and pulls out the stack of let from Frobisher to Sixsmith.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I know he would want you to have these.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: God... his letters. They pass the letters as if they were a child.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you...?

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I did. I’m sorry if that was invasive, I was trying to figure out what happened and I thought they might be important. She holds them like the are a sacred object.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: Important? Sometimes it seemed like they were the only thing in his life that really mattered to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dawn and Sixsmith stands before the only monument Frobisher ever mentioned: The tower.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t come looking for me, Sixsmith.  217. He pulls the collar of his natty gabardine coat up and he up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You can’t save me. I know now that my entire life has been leading to this point. INT. PAPA SONG’S SLAUGHTERHOUSE - DAWN - YEAR 2144 Sonmi watches as the cleaning crew hoses down the viscera covered machines, washing the blood into the grated floor drains.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I am grateful. Another shift crew begins to arrive. Her eyes look as har as stainless steel.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I’ve seen enough. EXT. PAPA SONG’S SLAUGHTERHOUSE - DAWN - YEAR 2144 They head down the gang way still wearing their masked coveralls. As they descend another group of Fabricants is being esco up by the armed security personnel. The Fabricants are smiling and excited. There is one that seems to be trailing slightly behind th others. She is a Yoona model. As they pass one another, Sonmi reaches out and grabs her The Yoona is startled. Sonmi stares at her from behind her mask.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Don’t go in there.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA 939
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Come with me. Chang puts his hand on Sonmi.  218.

dialogues.speaker: YOONA 939
dialogues.text: Let me go! She tears free and rushes to catch up with the others. Sonmi watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hidden behind shipping crates, Sonmi pulls her mask off a begins to sob. Chang puts his arms around her and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher puts the last spot of ink on the orchestration sheet.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s done. Finished in a frenzy that reminded me of our last night in Cambridge. Please take care of it. Keep it away from my family. Pater’ll sigh, “It’s no Eroica” and stuff it in a drawer. The truth is it is an incomparable creation. The music swirls and builds to climax in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher watches the sun come up, smoking his final cigarette. He looks like he has been up for days but he i smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Could never write anything near as good. Now, I’m a spent firework, but at least I’ve been a firework. The music is cut off as Frobisher hears someone climbing stairs. It seems too early or too cold to be a tourist. He hides around the corner, watching as a young man in a natty gabardine jacket emerges-- Sixsmith. Frobisher feels his heart choke his throat.  219. Sixsmith looks around the tower, just missing a crouched Frobisher in a dark alcove.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Watched my final sunrise, enjoyed a last cigarette. Didn’t think the view could be any more perfect until I saw that beat up trilby. Honestly, Sixsmith, as ridiculous as that thing makes you look, I don’t believe I’ve ever seen anything more beautiful. Thank you, my friend for being the one person on this earth who will actually miss ol’ Robert Frobisher. I can’t tell you what that means to me. Quietly, Frobisher slips back down the winding stairs, leaving Sixmith alone in the tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher finishes his last letter. Beside him is the Sex manuscript. The music returns.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Watched you for as long as I dared. I don’t believe it was a fluke that I saw you first. He signs the letter and puts it in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The world’s a shadow theatre, an opera and such things are writ large in its libretto. Don’t be too cross at my role. You’re a brilliant physicist but you couldn’t understand, no matter how much I explained. He picks up the Luger and goes to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs into the tub.  220.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I believe we do not stay dead long. As soon as my Luger lets me go, my birth, next time around will be on me in a heartbeat. He puts the gun in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is another world waiting for us, Sixsmith. A better world and I’1l be waiting for you there. Find me beneath the Corsican stars where we first kissed. Yours Eternally, R.F. The gun goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has set. The stars beginning to blink. Zachry and Catkin sit on the ledge of the Prescient’s hovercraft, legs dangling out over the water. Meronym is talking to DUOPHYSITE, the captain of the ship In the distance, plumes of smoke rise from the island, bl scars of violence. We hear a howling, angry wind that we have heard before. Catkin sees him first; Old Georgie hangs in the silhouett the trees. She clutches tight to her brother.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: It’s him, ain’t it? Zachry looks out towards the trees, but Georgie is no lon there.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Nay... jus’a wind. Meronym comes and sits with them.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: On’a’count’a what happen’d, my Captain say-soed to take you with us.  221.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Well, now, we ain’t be needin’ no charity.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: This ain’t no charity. Your prov’d yourself more’n’once. We could use your help. He mulls it over, not wanting to look too anxious.

dialogues.speaker: CATKIN
dialogues.text: I wanna go wit’Meronym!

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: An’jus‘where y’think y’goin? You Prescients same boat as us. You got no dwellin’place neither.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Nay, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: You think someun goin’t’hear your message an’come down ou’the sky?

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe one day.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Pffff. One day ain’t but a flea o’hope.

dialogues.speaker: MERONYM
dialogues.text: Yay, but fleas ain’t so easy to rid. She smiles and it lightens his heart. She covers his hand with her own and he knows that wheree this woman goes, he will follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang is curled around Sonmi’s body like protective armor Unable to sleep, she knows what she is going to do.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: That ship... She turns towards him.  222. SONMI-451 (CONT’D) That ship must be destroyed. Every slaughtership in the world must be sunk.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: The shipyards that built them must be demolished. The systems that facilitated them must be dismantled. The laws that permitted the systems must be torn down and reconstructed.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Every consumer, every politician, every Boardman must understand that Fabricants are Pureblood, be they grown in a wombtank or a womb.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: If persuasion does not work, we must fight to achieve this end whatever force is necessary.

dialogues.speaker: CHANG
dialogues.text: This is what we have been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the Sixsmith report as Megan hands it to Luisa R

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN
dialogues.text: My Uncle always used me to vet his math. I had to know if you were someone who was prepared to take this as far as it can go. Luisa can’t believe she has it in her hands. MEGAN (CONT’D) These people need to be held accountable.  223. Luisa nods.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make them pay. Luisa locks her jaw like a fighter going into the last ro

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: Count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archivist checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Our time is almost finished. Please tell me about your arrest.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: I was taken to a Union controlled satellite link. I broadcast my Catechisms to the Twelve States and the Four Off-World Colonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the same station that Zachry and Meronym used.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eighteen minutes later, the Enforcers attacked. A ferocious gunfight is watched in silence from Sonmi’s perspective behind the glass of the broadcast booth.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The report said that Commander Chang was killed in the assault. Sonmi watches helplessly as Chang is gunned down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain of the memory is hidden deep.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Would you say that you loved him?  224. She smiles and for a moment she is radiant.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Because very soon all of this is going to end. A door will close but another will open and I believe that when it does, I will find him there, waiting for me. EXT./INT. EWING’S HOME - DAY The door opens and Ewing is half-carried by Autua into th vestibule. Ewing’s wife TILDA sees him and rushes to him. He collapses into her arms. He cries, holding her, never more grateful for any moment his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and two Enforcers enter.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: On behalf of my Ministry and... myself, I thank you for this interview. She nods as the Enforcers unlock her cuffs. ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) If I may ask one last question: You had to know, the whole scheme engineered by Union, would fail.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Of course. This is exactly what General Apis laid out in that room to me. This was my destiny.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: What? To be... executed?  225.

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: If I had remained invisible, the truth would stay hidden. I couldn’t allow that. The Enforcers unlock her cuffs and lift her out of the ch

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: And what if no one believes this “truth”?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: That can’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVIST
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SONMI-451
dialogues.text: Because someone already does. Sonmi smiles as the Enforcers take her away. INT. THOMAS MOORE’S OFFICE - EVENING - YEAR 1846 Ewing enters using a cane. He looks better but not completely recovered. Haskell Moore, his father-in-law stands.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Good God, Adam, what are you doing here? The doctor said at least three weeks in bed.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but this couldn’t wait. Ewing sets his briefcase down. EWING (CONT’D) I’ve done a lot of thinking about my life, sir and I’ve come to certain conclusions. He removes the sealed contract from Horrox.  226.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Is that the contract for Reverend Horrox?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: It is indeed.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: I could have sent a boy-- Ewing holds the contract to the candle flame.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the devil are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: I owe my life to a self-freed slave. I cannot in good conscience participate in this kind of business any longer.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: What?! Are you insane?! You've just cost me a fortune! Goddamn you! If you weren’t my daughter’s husband I would fire you on the spot!

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Not necessary, sir. Here is my resignation. He hands him a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: When Tilda learns what you have done ---

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: She’s outside in the carriage. She came to demonstrate her support. Moore throws back the curtain to see his daughter Tilda s and wave from their carriage. Autua is beside her.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: The poison must have rotted your brain!

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Perhaps. If it has, I recommend it. I’ve not felt this good in years.  227.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: And just what in blazes do you think are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Spend my life shaping a world that I want my son to inherit, not one that I fear he shall inhabit.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Adam. Listen for the sake of my daughter and grandson, if not your own. There is a natural order to this world and those who try to upend it do not fare well. If you go to Georgia and try to tell upstanding people that they are merely white-washed niggers and that niggers are black- washed whites, you and your entire family will be spat on. You will be beaten. Shot at. Lynched or crucified. And for what, Adam? For what? No matter what you do, it will never amount to anything more than a single drop ina limitless ocean! Ewing stands at the door.

dialogues.speaker: EWING
dialogues.text: Yet what is any ocean but a multitude of drops? He shuts the door behind him. INT. LUISA’S APARTMENT - DAY - 1974 Luisa reads the paper with the huge headline: “LLOYD HOOK ARRESTED, PRESIDENT FORD VOWS TO ‘ROOT OUT CROOKS WHO BRI IGNOMINY TO CORPORATE AMERICA.’” Across from her on the couch, reading the same story in another paper is Javier.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: One for the good guys. Luisa smiles and offers her cup to cheers.

dialogues.speaker: LUISA REY
dialogues.text: I’1l drink to that.  228. They cheers and then she lifts her cup towards her father picture standing proudly. INT. CAVENDISH’S STUDY - NIGHT - YEAR 2009 Close as his empty glass of wine is filled. Cavendish finishes his memoirs.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In vino veritas. Middle age is flown, but it is attitude, not years, that condemns one to the ranks of the Undead, or else prof- fers salvation. A woman comes around to the back of his chair and massage his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Outside, fat snowflakes are falling on slate roofs and granite walls. Like Solzhenitsyn laboring in Vermont, I shall beaver away in exile, far from the city that knit- ted my bones. Cavendish finishes and takes her hand leading her around sit with him. It is Ursula.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unlike Solzhenitsyn, I shan't be alone. He pours her a glass and they smile and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire has burned out.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Firey’s dyin’. Jus’as well. My yarnin’s done. ADAM, a young boy who could be a young Zachry with dark s sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: ‘Bout time! Can we go home now? Around the fire are a dozen young faces, children and gra children of obviously mixed races.  229.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Oh yay! Go! Ge’on then y’damn sluggabuggahs! Try to tell you what’s what-- Ge’on! The kids tumble and dash away, heading towards a distant house glowing warmly. Beyond the home, there are the twinkling spires of a futu city. Zachry remains behind. He looks up. Two moons, one nearly full, the other almost new gleam with pale purple light. MIRO, a young girl who looks like what Meronym must have looked like as a child, lingers with him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRO
dialogues.text: You like it out here, don’t you Grampy? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Supposin’ it ‘minders me’a my Valley. She stares with him at the star field beyond.

dialogues.speaker: MIRO
dialogues.text: Which is the earth? He points to a bright star.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: That un there. The blue shimmerer. As they gaze upwards, we see the back of Zachry’s head wh was covered by his hair when he was younger; there near t top of his spine is a comet-shaped birthmark.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Gettin’ cold. She helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: MIRO
dialogues.text: Are you gonna tell us ‘bout the woahsome ship and the big sleep and all the nex’nexs.

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Nay... your Grammy tells the nex’nexs better’n’me.  230. He takes her hand and they head away from us, towards the home.

dialogues.speaker: MIRO
dialogues.text: Do you still love Grammy?

dialogues.speaker: ZACHRY
dialogues.text: Your Grammy was the bes’thing that ever happ’n’d to me.
